I was initially a little hesitant about this scanner due to its portable size. However, I was happily surprised to see that my expectations were exceeded. The quality of the scans is really great for something this small. Plus, being able to wirelessly scan receipts is a huge plus. I don't know of any other scanners this small that can do that. 

Despite the instructions not explicitly saying that they're for this model of the scanner, setting up the scanner was also fairly easy because the instructions are pretty detailed.  The included instructions link you to the download page on Epson's website. From there it was just installing one program. Took about 5 minutes in total. Once the software is installed you're prompted to calibrate the scanner. This was done with the included calibration sheet (much like how you calibrate a printer). Again, very straight forward and only took a few minutes. 

One of the features I really like is that the PDFs the scanner creates are OCR enabled (i.e., the computer picks up the text and is searchable). This is a huge time saver for me as it'll allow me to search through my receipts by date, location, etc. 

While being "green" isn't important to everyone, I really appreciated Epson going the extra mile and making this out of recycled plastics. It's not something that makes the scanner perform better, but makes me feel a little better about having it. 

This is a review for the RapidReceipt RR-60 Mobile Receipt Scanner that I received free of charge to do a beta test and review.

This is a very capable little scanner, so I would like to start with that. Between the size and features it is a nice quality product, however, I have some gripes that stop me from giving it five stars. 

First is the difference in cost between this model and the wireless one (RR-70W) is not justified in todays day and age with wireless chips being as cheap as they are and there being such a limited market for a USB *ONLY* version of this consumer product. The second is the macOS software requiring some configuring to scan a receipt instead of just working right out of the box. The setting I am referring to is the "Document Size", and the "Auto" size does not work for receipts past a certain length and required to be set to "Auto Long". Once that was cleared up however, the hardware works like a charm for scanning to a document. The software for interpreting the receipts is really not up to my standard and was not very accurate despite much trial and mostly error. 

Besides the interpretation part of the software, the scanner produces a nice clear image quickly and easily via the included USB-A to Micro-USB cable. After changing the aforementioned "Document Size" setting it had no problem scanning a long Kroger grocery receipt, which gives it a huge advantage over most flat-top scanners with their limited scan length. For those with a limited desk area who are handling multiple odd-length documents often, this is an ideal choice (however I personally would opt for the wireless option to reduce clutter even further). I also do like the look of this scanner for what its worth. This is a review for the RapidReceipt RR-60 Mobile Receipt Scanner that I received free of charge to do a beta test and review.

My new Epson RapidReceipt 60 scanner is convenient.  I am replacing a printer/scanner combo.  With my printer/scanner combo, it would only scan one page at a time and only scan to a jpeg (photo) format.  I would have to then save to pdf file and then have lots of separate pdf for one document.  Not, with the RR-60!  
     I am not tech savvy and need step by step directions.  This scanner is almost plug and play.  There are directions and on the website better directions with cartoon graphics.  You have to plug the scanner into your computer to charge it.  And to be honest, I think that is they only way to turn it on.  I can not find how to turn it on/off.  I thought I read it was supposed to be wireless, but I do not see how to do that.  The instructions show the other model RR-70W being able to scan to a cell phone, so maybe it is that model that is wireless.  
     You can only scan one sheet of paper at a time, and it is one sided only (not duplex scanning).  But that is ok.  The scanner is fast.  And you can rearrange your scans so if you scan pages 1, 3, 5, 2, 4, 6 in that order, you can later numerically order the scans to be in order:  That screen allows you to crop, delete, rotate, and organize the scans in any order you want; there is also a zoom feature so you can see the scan’s detail as well.  
     You can save in pdf, word, and even in powerpoint format.  The negative is once it saves, it becomes a blurry/fuzzy pdf.  It is no longer clear and crisp.  
     You can also scan and organize your receipts.  I started scanning my receipts.  The scanning of a 8X10 document is easier than receipts, you will have to make sure you are giving it a tiny push to get the receipt to be sucked in.  There is a “review invoices/receipts” feature that you can organize into categories and even upload it to certain tax preparation programs.  At this time, you can scan to quicken and turbo tax.  Although I employ a different tax preparation software, I find the receipt scanning very convenient; it still organizes it for me compared to my shoebox of receipts I have now.  
     You can also scan photos too!  This so much more convenient than the printer/scanner combo I already have and the product is a little bit better than taking a photo with your cell phone too.  But the finished product (jpeg) still has a slight blur like the pdf.  
     I would give this 4 stars out of 5 because of the slight fuzzy/blurry finished product once it is saved to my computer (Windows 10 based).  This is a review for the RapidReceipt RR-60 Mobile Receipt Scanner that I received free of charge to do a beta test and review.

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] I absolutely LOVE this scanner. its so small and light weight and scan FAST !! It easily scans everything from Receipts to Ids. [This review was collected as part of a promotion.] This little scanner is excellent. The scans are clean and it does both color and black and white. It sometimes needs help feeding long receipts through or they will jam, but nothing a little guiding with your hand can't help. I love the Epson ScanSmart Software. It allows you to sequentially scan multiple scans, review them, and then export them or download them separately or all at once to your given folder or business management software like QuickBooks. When scanned to the invoice/receipt manager software from Epson, it can actually auto detect vendors like USPS for easier classification and tax management. It is only about 11 inches long and is super light, taking up hardly any footprint at all on your desk or table. Very light to carry in bag, have to download a file to any computer you want to use it on.  Once download is complete, it is super simple to use. The Epson RR-60 is a fast and light weight scanner that plugs into your PC via USB connection.  It’s been super helpful for me since I’m working more from home. I’m able to scan documents easily to the Epson SmartScan software. 

You’ll need to download the Epson SmartScan software via Epson’s website. A quick Google search of “Epson RR-60 drivers” will take you to the support page to download the drivers and SmartScan software. It’s very easy to install on your PC. Just make sure it’s plugged in during install so it’ll connect. 

Included also is a license to Nuance PowerPDF software. It allows you to edit PDFs, e-signature, create forms, add text, and much more. It’s a great supplemental software to have if you desire to do more with your documents!

Overall I am satisfied with the Epson RR-60 and would recommend to anyone looking for something portable and easy to use!

The Epson RR-60 is fast and light-weight portable document scanner. You can scan receipts, documents, and even photos! I use it primarily for the document scanning since I work from home! It connects to your PC via USB connection. 
Before you can use it you’ll need to download Epson SmartScan software. Just Google the model number of the scanner and you’ll find the Epson support page to install the driver and scanner software. 
Included in the packaging is a license to the Nuance Power PDF software which allows one to edit PDFs, add text, sign documents via e-signature, and more! This is supplemental software that is great if you need to do additional formatting to your scanned PDFs or PDFs downloaded online. 
Overall I’m satisfied with the Epson RR-60 and will use it often!
Note: This is a review for the RapidReceipt RR-60 Mobile Receipt Scanner that I received free of charge to do a beta test and review.

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] Epson rapid receipt scanner is easy to use and pretty much just plug and play. Windows OS recognizes the hardware with no issues. Even though it can be used once it is connected, I recommend downloading the software from the manufacturer for better performance. The scanner itself is very light and in a compact format perfect for on the go productivity. 

When ready to use all you have to do is press the scan button on the device and it will automatically lunch the scanner software. Lightly insert the receipt, document or business card in the feeder and the scanner will do it's magic. The dedicated software which you have to download from the Epson website is also easy to use. 

The software has a lot of scanning options including PDF and a dedicated receipt and invoice format. For anyone keeping track of their financials I see the receipt and invoice option beneficial. That option will automatically extract important information such as payment option, tax, total, date etcetera and then it can be exported to various formats including excel, quickbooks, and turbotax. 

If you work on the go and keep track of your financials this scanner will do the job just right efficiently and quietly. This device does not have a built in battery or wireless connectivity, it has to be connected via USB to be used. In the box you get the scanner, micro USB cable and manuals.

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] The RR-60 scanner is a MUST for anyone who does itemized deductions for tax purposes, or for any small business owner who have to keep receipts of everything, but in my case, I work in Healthcare administration and we have satellite offices that I move in between 3 or 4 times a week. this has been a great addition to my laptop bag because it is very small and portable, have endless saving options for scanned documents as you can scan and then save into Google Drive, DropBox, send via email, send to evernote, powerpoint, excel, word, or onedrive as you can see in the attached image.
the smart scan utility also gives you the option to save as PDF, searchable PDF (OCR), PNG, JPEG, TIFF, and more.
you can also use the bonus software that comes with the smartscan utility to to manage invoices/ receits and import data from scanned documents and export it to Tax softwares like TurboTax. 
This is not the first Epson mobile scanner that I owned. I have been using Epson mobile scanners for over 4 years and those scanners are still working with no issues whatsoever. 
the scanner is very small and fits in my laptop bag with no issues.
The scanner comes with a quick user guide and a USB to Micro USB cable to power the scanner and connect it to a Computer and a cleaning sheet and a calibration sheet.
I know that this will live for years to come and will be a work horse regardless of its small size.

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] I can't say enough wonderful things about the DJI Osmo Mobile 6 stabilizer. All that is required is to download the app onto your phone and you're ready to start creating videos. 

Let's discuss the features. The first feature of course is the stabilizing feature. It does a great job at keeping the camera steady as I even had my daughter hold the camera and check out how well it stabilized. Okay, that's just one little feature. Another great feature is with the app open, you can set the stabilizer up to actively track someone or something. I first tried the feature on a cat (The cat wasn't amused), then I tried the feature on myself just walking around the house, and the stabilizer tracked perfectly (It was a little slow but very smooth). The app itself has so many different features that I can't even list them all, as I'm continuously learning about them as I use the stabilizer. Another great thing about the stabilizer and the app is that as you access new features it gives you simple step-by-step tutorials to follow, which makes learning how to use the stabilizer a breeze. 

Overall, I'm super impressed with it, from the active track to the features on the app itself. This is a great product!

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] While great for TikTok videos & vertical filming, the horizontal vlogging while tilted is bad. Tilt motion is limited making walking vlogs with the front facing camera a challenge. Also you can only selfie film yourself using the front facing camera. The camera would often lose track of me and I constantly had to readjust. It doesn’t have the full range of motion which I need for outdoor filming. Vertical movements from the top to bottom shows the flaw in the design. The quick setup is great. It’s very light but sturdy. I like the built in selfie stick, and the software is pretty good. You really need to think ahead about what type of filming you’ll do as this unit has a lot of great features. The issue is that it doesn’t meet my needs and after getting a gimbal where I can vlog myself using the rear facing camera I realize that this unit is not for me. It’s not a bad product, but you really need to know what your needs are before buying a gimbal to film. In certain situations this product is perfect. It really is a well made good product depending on what you need to accomplish with your filming.

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] I am not a professional photographer, but I am a bit of a photography enthusiast.  I mostly focused on still images mainly because handheld video is never easy to get right.  

So this is the first gimbal I have ever used and I must say I am very impressed.  Video while moving is super steady and the ability to track targets is incredibly useful.  Still coming up with different ways to use this feature as it opens up so many possibilities.

In the box you get the gimbal, phone clip and tripod and charging cable

Out of the box, set up is easy and intuitive - scan a QR code and download an app, pair the gimbal with Bluetooth.  The app offers lots of training for newbies like myself via tutorial videos.  And you pick up a lot just by experimenting with the different features.  

Physical controls are in easy to use places, and the wheel for zoom and button for swapping between stills and video are very useful.  The gimbal is well balanced and ergonomically designed.

This is an easy device to recommend to anyone wanting to take their cell phone videos to the next level.

I have OM4 and tried OM5. The new OM6 has some nice features, like the wheel on the side and quick mode change capability. However, the battery life is still much worse than the OM4. The tilt range is very limited.

Cool features, works good and fast. Not feeling the limited motion with tilt locked. Your phone WILL tilt if you move the wand up or down passed a certain point. Not a true tilt lock, like the Osmo Pocket device.

Very handy item. Able to take still and movie iphotos without any shake. Various settings allow for several shooting modes. I would recommend this to anyone interested in elevating their pictures to a new level.

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] Yes. I'm an Android enthusiast. My Samsung S22 Ultra is a great phone, but I understand Apple gets a lot of the third party compatibility. Maybe that's due to the fragmentation of Android. Who knows? But I really don't appreciate companies that claim to be compatible with Android who are not truly compatible. This DJI Osmo Mobile 6 is a perfect example of that. Apple has an official app you can find in their app store, but Android is left with an APK (that my anti-virus program warned me about downloading) that needs to be side loaded. There needs to be more effort in labeling this on the box and in the product description. However, it still works for stabilizing, just don't think you'll be able to take advantage of all the zoom features and controlling options the stabilizer has. Luckily, I am mainly using it for family memories, so my Scorsese skills in film making will not need a lot of these controls. But I'd love for it to be available if the product is priced the same no matter if it all works or not. It'd be nice to have an Android edition, that may lack all features, but would be cheaper. The build quality is excellent though. Not too heavy, but hefty enough to feel the quality materials used. All in all, I'm glad I own it because as a stabilizer it works well. I just wish it was truly compatible with Android officially.

This is a solid and portable gimble, from its hardware to its mobile app! It has a slight learning curve but is very easy to grasp. 

You will have a wide range of stable and directional control for your videos/photos, and the extender arm and the tripod attachment make it a bonus for hitting those angles or those POV and selfie shots. 

I am also impressed with the thumb access to all of those buttons to trigger all of your iPhone's video and photo features without using the touchscreen. It is a very efficient and well-thought-out user experience. It would also be great if the trigger finger button could be customized as the video record or photo snapshot button.

My only gripe is the MagSafe clamp for iPhones using a protective case, as it could interfere with your buttons and continuously trigger them. It takes a little finesse, and it depends on your protective case, but you might be able to avoid it. Centering the MagSafe clamp is not difficult once you have done it a few times.

In some cases, you might need to offset the positioning of the clamp to avoid button triggering, which could also affect the gimble's auto-balancing feature in landscape mode. The gimble may also use more battery life to maintain its balance during landscape mode.

However, if you still have button/balancing issues with the DJI MagSafe clamp, I came across a perfect adapter mount if you Google "DJI magnetic ring holder phone clamp mount." It works perfectly with Magsafe iPhone cases and with the DJI Osmo 6 gimble!

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] The DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Stabilizer is one of the coolest products I’ve used in some time. Right out of the set up is super easy, scan the QR code to take you to the app store and download the DJI Mimo App and pair it via Bluetooth. Once in the app there are multiple tutorial videos that help you get familiar with the DJI Osmo Mobile 6, which is a nice feature to have so you're not having to Google or go on Youtube to learn how to properly use this device.  The metal mounting clip is one of the better mounts I have come across, in that it stretches wide enough to grasp around my Iphone 14 Pro Max with a case on, I was for sure thinking that my case was going to be too bulky for it but it was able to. The Mimo software is great in that it basically mimics my iPhone’s camera interface but with some more options on the screen depending on which setting you are in, such as in photo mode where there is a shutter timer where you can pick from 3 seconds, 5 seconds and 7 seconds. In the Video mode it allows you to pick the resolution (720P,1080P or 4K) and what frame rate you would like to shoot in, which is super nice being able to pick that right from the camera interface and not having to dive into the setting to find it. Then the most outstanding feature of the DJI Osmo Mobile 6 has to be the head tracking feature in that when shooting video, a green box shows up and the arm will literally move and follow your head as you move which is perfect for filming things such as content or family videos. The buttons on the DJI Osmo Mobile 6 are very intuitive in that you get a Zoom knob, a record button, a focus stick that allows you to move the arm like you would with the right stick on a game controller, and A landscape to vertical button. There is a trigger button on the back of the handle that is not as intuitive and I highly recommend watching all the tutorial videos to learn all of its little tricks. In summary I think this is one of the best filming accessories you can buy to truly get the best photos and videos on your cell phone.

Bought this item almost 2 months ago for real estate film making with my iPhone. I had had the OM5 and to be honest, not much of a difference, at least for what I need it. If you have the OM5 model and you don't think the zoom button is something useful for you, than no need for upgrades. Otherwise, if you don't have phone stabilizer, definitely buy! Very noob friendly and useful for great content!

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] The DJI Osmo Mobile 6  Gimbal is a very high quality, well designed mobile stabilizer.

But as an owner of the Google Pixel 6 I have to point out some of the negatives right from the start.

First, the DJI MIMO app is not available in the Google Play Store. In order to download the app you must go into settings and allow download and installation of apps from unknown sources. That’s right, you must download an app from a Chinese company directly, without being verified by Google. This of course is accompanied by a warning that downloading this app may cause harm to your device and other apps on your device.  Not very comforting. In addition, not all features work on Android phones. Each phone model is different and therefore this may vary by device.

Also, I found that my phone was hotter in the Osmo than it is normally when its in camera mode, and the battery drained much quicker.

One other issue is the magnetic clip holder. It goes on the Pixel phone on top of the volume switch. If placed exactly in the middle of the phone it presses on the down volume switch and turns the volume all the way down.

The focus scroll wheel is also not functional with my Pixel phone.

The device itself is very high quality, very ergonomically designed. It is very well balanced in the hand and does not cause hand fatigue. All buttons and switches are placed within easy reach.

DJI has videos in the app to fully explain the operation of each switch.

In the box you get the magnetic phone clip, the stabilizer unit, an attachable tripod and a charging cable.

After you download the app, the Osmo 6 will automatically turn on when you attach the phone and off when the phone is removed.

One of my favorite features is face lock while in video. Your phone will lock on your face and follow you around. You can place the phone in the Osmo with the tripod, put it on a flat surface and record yourself while moving, and the camera will follow you. A push of a button will automatically switch between portrait and landscape.

Image stabilization is of course a main reason for buying this device and it performs better than any phone by itself.

There is a scroll wheel for zooming in and out as well as a button for switching between video and photo.

There are way too many features to mention, however DJI does a great job of explaining the functions in video and with hints that appear on the screen.

I would love to recommend this device, and I would to any iPhone user. But if you are an Android user I would weigh the positives and negatives before purchasing. I don’t know why DJI has put Android users in this situation and I hope that this situation changes sooner rather than later. This could easily be a5 start review if not for the software issues for Android.

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] The Osmo Mobile 6 is a very fun smartphone gimbal stabilizer packed with great features to help you capture smooth, creative footage and fun photos. I like that a lot of what the gimbal has to offer is right at my finger tips. Changing modes, camera orientation, and angles is a click of a button or a push of the joystick away from personal customization. Each mode focuses on customizing which axis has priority over the movement of the camera. More on the modes below.

DJI MIMO APP
To get the most out of the DJI Osmo Mobile 6, I suggest downloading the DJI Mimo app which allows you to use all the buttons to their fullest potential. Using the DJI Mimo app will unlock these additional button or handle features:
Switch between front and back camera
Switch between photo and video mode
Use the focusing or zoom wheel
Use the record button

The features listed above are not available to use with my Google Pixel Camera App. Here are the Osmo Mobile 6 buttons or handle features you can use WITHOUT the Mimo app (say like with your phone’s native camera app, these will just inherently work if the gimbal is on and the phone is mounted properly): 
Joystick
Switching between Landscape or Portrait orientation
Changing Modes
Re-centering with trigger button
Using the trigger to “lock” the view

The DJI Mimo app is very neat. I really like the subject-follow feature because it essentially allows you to set the camera down and let the app/camera follow your movement even without handling the gimbal itself. This is possible with the included mountable tripod which is an awesome accessory that’s included with this kit. My phone is not compatible with the focusing feature so the wheel on the side only allows me to zoom, not smoothly I might add, but not a dealbreaker.

EXTENDING FEATURE
This gimbal also extends so you can get high up drone-like shots or very low shots. It’s like a selfie stick, but better because it’s also a gimbal! The only downside to this is that because of the extendable feature, you have to be careful when taking it to amusement parks as they often don’t allow extendable devices like this one.

4 GIMBAL MODES
Out of the 4 modes, the one that’s more “general” or easiest to work with is the first one: Follow mode. It’s going to either pan up or down, left or right, depending on which way you move the camera, and it won’t “roll” sideways. 

The second mode: Tilt Lock, will do just that, lock the tilt and allow you to pan left or right with natural hand movement. If you want to change the angle of the tilt in Tilt Lock mode, just use the joystick to bring the camera’s view up or down. 

The third mode: FPV will actually follow any movement on all 3 axes, so you get more dynamic or creative shots with this mode as it will “roll” (turn the camera sideways) as you’re following a subject. 

The fourth mode: SpinShot allows you to naturally “roll” the camera sideways while still facing a subject, as well as lets the joystick rotate the camera as well, whereas in the other modes, the joystick is moving the camera angle up, down, left or right. SpinShot allows the camera to tilt sideways. To get a visual of what this looks like, look straight ahead then lean your head to one side like you’re putting your ear to your shoulder, and keep looking straight. This is the “roll” effect I’m talking about.

OVERALL
I love playing with this gimbal. I take it to local music shows and plan to take it to a festival to get some smooth footage and fun pictures. It’s great for people who like to film videos whether it’s for an event or an artistic video piece. This gimbal has plenty of modes to work with to get super creative shots or just get nicely stable footage. I’ve only had to charge it once so far and I’ve used it a few times. There’s a nice indicator screen that shows you modes, battery level, and will let you know with a red light above the battery indicator if the magnet is not secured properly. I can definitely recommend this gimbal to anyone who likes video tech or looking to gift it.

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] The DJI Osmo 6 Phone Stabilizer Gimbal is a handheld device that using a gyro-type system, will let you place your smartphone on it, and it stabilizes the phone for photos and videos while you are handholding the device.  As you move, it moves with you, but your phone seems to “float” in it’s holder, not moving at all unless you get carried away and move too much or too fast.  But with normal panning, walking, even jogging, your photos and videos will remain pretty much motion/jerky free.

The Osmo 6 has a main body that consists of a hand grip and varied controls, along with an arm that extends (which turns it on when you do so).  A strong magnetic disk with stretching clips wraps around your phone and then sticks onto this arm, so you can use it while moving around.  The arm itself also has a telescoping feature so you can extend it and get more than 8 inches of reach as well (think of it as a souped-up selfie stick if you want).  A separate tripod attachment screws onto the bottom and has three legs you can extend – this way, you can use the Gimbal as a tripod for video, photo, podcasts, etc.  It’s a standard mount so you can also use many normal sized tripods as well.

You need to download the DJI app for best results.  Once installed and set up, your phone connects to the Osmo 6 via Bluetooth, and when you magnetically snap it onto the Gimbal, the app auto-launches on your phone.  There’s a variety of tutorials teaching you how to use the device, and it connects to your phone's album(s) with permission, so you can use it through the app.  It WILL work without the app, but I found some of the features to work in a clunky way without it.

The controls on the hand grip allow you to pan the camera, back and forth, up and down, control zoom and focus, flip from the main back camera to the front camera, re-center the phone, and track subjects of your choosing, and more.  Some buttons have more than one function based on how many times you click them.  I will say, the sheer number of click combinations for different functions at first seems a bit overwhelming and you will find yourself referring to the manual many times to remember what does what.  It’s not the best experience in my opinion, but in time, all of the combinations should begin to sink in.  

The Osmo 6 does work as advertised.  Panning at a fairly good clip, it keeps my video steadier than I can do by hand, even if I use the phone’s built-in stabilizer.  Likewise, if taking still photos and you are moving a bit, it will help keep things steady hence, sharper photos and videos. I have a medical condition that sometimes makes it hard to remain super steady, and this definitely made a huge difference. I’ve only seen one or two millisecond hiccups where it stalled, but it hasn’t been common.  The motor is not loud.  Battery life is very good, and it charges via a USB-C port on the side of the main body.  A battery icon on the main body tells you when you’re low.  

This isn’t the type of device that every person with a phone will want to invest in or spend the money for, especially if you really just use your phone for casual photography with an occasional video.  But if you are more serious about your pics and vids and take a good number of both, and/or you like to experiment with podcasting or making more semi-pro videos, then it’s a worthy investment to make your media look more professionally done.  Not perfect, but recommended if you need it.

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] The DJI Osmo Mobile 6 is DJI’s latest phone gimbal promising an all in one experience. This gimbal combines a gimbal and selfie stick into one along with DJI’s Mimo app for “efficient shooting, editing, and sharing” which may or may not be your actual experience. After a few days I have to say this gimbal isn’t for everyone. 

In the Box:

-	Osmo Mobile 6 Gimbal
-	Magnetic Phone Clamp
-	Gimbal Tripod
-	Power Cable
-	Storage Bag

Setup:

For best results, you need to download the DJI app which is where you might start to notice a different perspective in the overall user experience whether you are an IPhone or Android user. For Android, you must download the app via APK (because the Google Play Store does not have an official app to download). The APK warns you that the file may contain viruses and harm your device. Chances are it will not but it’s not something you feel overly enthused about.

After the app is installed, the phone connects to the gimbal via Bluetooth. The phone itself sits inside a magnetic clamp and then snaps on and off of the gimbal. The process is very simple to get the phone on and off of the gimbal however the clamp may sit in a problem spot depending on your phone design. This varies greatly but if you have buttons in the center or just off center of the edges on your phone, this may be a problem.

The bottom of the gimbal features a threaded mount to install the tripod mount. Simply screw it on and off and it acts as a tripod. If you want to use the selfie stick function of the gimbal just pull the end up/out and you can use the gimbal in an extended mode.

The buttons on the hand grip gimbal portion allow you to control most functions of the gimbal/phone app without using the touch screen of the phone itself. You can change modes of the type of shot you want, pan, tilt, control zoom and focus, flip camera views, re-center your phone, and activate/disable active track, etc. If you double click some buttons it will act as different functions. If you are familiar with other DJI products, this will seem very intuitive.

Usage:

The gimbal does exactly what it claims. It will keep the phone nearly perfectly steady with little effort on your end. This will be substantially better than any optical/digital stabilization in your phones camera from the factory. Sometimes if may often work better with the gimbal if you disable any stabilization on your phone while using the gimbal but this is optional and your experience may differ depending on the phone. 

My only issue that I ran into was the pivot point for the selfie stick always was at the wrong angle when you put it back down into its regular position. So the bottom motor would rub on the edge of the plastic body. It does feel quite delicate when you are pull and pushing on the stick to raise and lower it but I suppose that’s what it was designed to do. 

Overall:

The DJI Osmo Mobile 6 is a great gimbal for your phone to achieve cinematic like footage with excellent stabilization. My biggest complaints are more to do with the Mimo app rather than the gimbal itself. For years, DJI have not released official apps on the Play Store for some reason. I wish they would release an official build so people don’t have to feel like they are letting access to their phone via an APK. In addition, the features should be better optimized for the Android platform like they are for IPhone users. Outside of this, I believe it is a very useful tool for those looking for an affordable all-in-one type of device to create better content.

The Osmo Mobile 6 includes several shooting modes, including ActiveTrack 4.0, which allows the gimbal to automatically track and follow a subject, and Gesture Control, which allows you to take selfies or start/stop recording by making hand gestures.

In terms of battery life, the Osmo Mobile 6 has a run time of up to 7.5 hours, which is an improvement over its predecessor. It also features a USB-C port for charging your phone while you're using the gimbal.

Overall, the DJI Osmo Mobile 6 is an excellent smartphone gimbal that offers a great balance of features, ease of use, and portability. If you're looking for a way to improve the quality of your smartphone video footage, the Osmo Mobile 6 is definitely worth considering.

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] I love it, it really helps with my photography!!!!

The bad:
1. The app isn't on the play store I would assume because it doesn't meet Google's guidelines.  You need to change phone settings to allow this install.
2. It only supports the 1x and 3x cameras on the Galaxy S22 Ultra.  Why have a zoom wheel if it can't even access the 10x optical camera?  Also, the 0.6X camera is a no go.
3. Active track has trouble starting using the hand signal when the background is busy.
4. Camera and Video functionality is very limited in the mimo app.  No HDR, only 30fps support, no geotagging photos, no pro camera etc..   If you switch to the default phone camera app you cant even use the start/stop button on the gimbal, there is 0 connectivity there. 
5. The ability to look down is very limited. Placing this on a table using its mini stand you cannot look down very far.
6. Active track only works on the 1x lens.  As soon as you hit 3x it stops zooming while active track is on.  

The Good:
1. It is light, quick to setup and not much of a learning curve.
2. It fits the large S22 Ultra in a thin case and motors can handle it. 
3. Active track when working is great.  
4. Gimbal serves the purpose of making video smooth.
5. Price isn't bad compared to other DJI gimbals.

I could get over almost all the negatives if they could get all the cameras supported on this popular phone and if active track could work across each camera.  

Photo is GoPro in the Volta Handle next to the Insta360 X3, next to this OM6 Gimbal, next to the Ronin SC Gimbal with a APS-C camera.

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] Overall - Crazy fast feature rich gimble Loaded with Features !


This is great fun and turns your cell phone into device that shoots incredibly good video in almost any situation. A mature and feature rich software support means you can connect a phone, pop it on and just go at it in a few minutes. If you have never used a gimble before - I would recommend the built in tutorial along with YouTube tips and tricks.

As someone who owns two other older gimbles - This instantly outmoded them. The functionality offered and the reaction speed with which this works is roughly one internet year ahead of anything else I have used. It's awesome.   

Software - It just works. Install the app, pair the device and allow it permissions. The controls just work as they should on both my older android and current iPhone. First time setup was under 2 with both phones I tried. 

Real World Size and Weight - Folds to very compact. Weight = 1.01Lbs which I consider negligible if you are carrying other gear. I budget packing space in common things I "know" - I.e. this device takes the  space of one 16oz bottle of water in my day hike-bike-trip bag.

"Torture Testing" - I tried every listed feature on the website - they all worked !  
I did this as a way to familiarize myself with the controls after completing the built in tutorial as
 well as a tips and tricks on YouTube tutorial. For laughs I threaded it into a mount I have on my mountain bike bars. Trail riding is notoriously hard to shoot whereas you want some amount of jolts and bumps to make it feel more real to the viewer -  It kept up ! I then realized I could use that to grab some subject tracking shots of a buddy I was riding with. Much to my surprise I ended up some really cool footage via that technique whereas I was only trying to test out the stabilization in what I considered an impossible shooting scenario. Next, an idea struck - Subject track a far off object to the side while riding a trail - cool shots of everything whipping by. This gimble is unstoppable and vastly exceeded my expectations ! 

Pros - 
Reaction Speed is top notch !
CAN be charged/powered while in use.
Mature product software + constant software improvements. 

Cons - 
Slight learning curve - The tutorial and YouTube are your friends !
Is it waterproof ? - No.    

Overall - Love it ! I'll be handing down or recycling two other gimbles and I'll likely purchase a second one shortly.

I'm not sure how this wasn't included in any reviews, but this basically doesn't work with Android. The DJI Mimo App is not in the Play store and if you go to the DJI website to try to download it, you get a sketchy APK that is blocked by like 99% of IT administrators. Reading between the lines, there must be some serious security and/or stability concerns with this app, and it's supposed to be user friendly so APK hacking around security restrictions is not exactly the "start it up right out of the box" they advertise. The app is not extraneous either, most of the buttons don't work if you don't have the app, basically you can just pan up, down, and side-to-side. Zoom doesn't work, record doesn't work, none of the other buttons do anything. Total waste of money.

The lronlem is the biggest reason i pirchased was for perfectly framed level shots. However i have to manually adjust the gimble 2 degrees every time to get it level. Defeats the puppse of using the magnets to quickly attach your phone  for a quick shot. Each time i have to open up the app after phone is connected and adjust 2 degrees :(

I also love the LightCut app which makes editing videos a breeze. If you’re thinking about getting this, do it. You wont regret it!

I honestly love this gimbal! I’ve had other gimbals before and hardly used them because it simply took too long to balance my phone every time! Sure this gimbal has a limited range of motion… but the best gimbal is one that you use! This one, you stick the magnet on the middle of your phone, and then it takes literally 5 seconds to be completely set up and ready to go every time after that. The gimbal is also small, so it fits right in to my Fanny pack! Also like the extension

I recently purchased the Dji Osmo mobile 6 Mobile Gimbal and I have been blown away by its performance. It has quickly become my go-to accessory when shooting video on my phone.

The gimbal is incredibly easy to use and provides smooth, stable video footage. It has helped me capture stunning footage on-the-go and has saved me countless hours of video editing in post-production.

One of the things I love about this gimbal is its compact size. It easily fits in my pocket or camera bag, making it a great tool for traveling. It also has a long battery life so I can shoot for hours without needing to recharge.

Overall, I highly recommend the Mobile Gimbal to anyone who wants to take their mobile videography to the next level. It is a must-have accessory for anyone who wants to capture stunning video footage on their phone.

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] The Razer Kaira Pro is a black headset with green accents that matches the color of the Xbox systems. While it totes as being a headset for Xbox, you can technically use it with anything that connects to bluetooth. It features two plush, comfy headphones, a detachable microphone and a lux braided charging cord. The headphones feature the razor logo that changes a variety of colors while in use- from green to purple to blue to yellow etc. I mean, they look really cool. But, they’re just as functional as they are stylish. The ear cups twist at a 45 degree angle making it extremely easy to take them on and off. Taking them out of the package, I was very impressed by the super clean and sleek design. It truly felt like I was opening up a luxury item. These are the most comfortable headphones that I’ve ever worn. They have breathable, memory foam air cushions. I love how easy the mic is to detach- it just plugs into a jack. It was extremely easy to pair my headphones with my Xbox as well as my phone via Bluetooth when I just wanna listen to music. Another fun feature, is that all of the controls are on the ears in the headset itself. One ear features the power button, a mic mute switch and a volume dial that beeps when you’ve reached maximum volume. The other ear features a Bluetooth button and a game/chat balance wheel to increase the in-game volume and decrease the voice chat volume or vice versa. The Razer HyperClear Supercardoid Mic gives you crystal clear talk sound. This is an awesome pair of headphones that are super functional and stylish at the same time! This is for that next level gaming!

Since Black Friday is going on wanted to share my experience. Have had these since March of 2022 and I have to say these are hands down the best headphones under $100 when on sale, they are a steal! At full price I feel for $30 more you should opt for the new Nova 7x by Arctis.

Pros
- Sound Quality
- Ease of use (Built for Xbox so there is a razer xbox app in the xbox store for tuning)
- Amazing FPS, pair this with the free Microsoft Sonic or purchase Dolby Atmos and you have full spacial hearing
- Mic is awesome, Team can always here me even when I whisper, it does pick up background noise as well so don't annoy your friends with music in the background

Cons
- Connection, at times the connection randomly drops for no reason at all, they just disconnect for a few seconds. It's very annoying especially when playing something like MW2 because you lose that edge. I have yet to figure out what causes the drop
- Noise Canceling, it's pretty good at blocking out most noises but if you live in a noisy city you will 100% here the trash trucks, traffic, etc. If you sit close to a window that is, if you are already pretty well isolated then these are perfect ( Parents you might have to go tap your kids on the shoulder to get their attention )

Overall these are great cans, at $90 when on sale. As mentioned at full price there are already other great competitors but at $90 there is no comparison. If you are thinking on passing on these don't. If you have an extra $70 to spare go for the Turtle Beach 700 Gen 2 Max, those are hands down the best under $200 cans when on sale lastly is money is no object, buy the Arctis Nova Pros (Wired or Wireless) Hands down the best gaming headphones in existence at the moment.

Happy Holidays!

I needed a pair of wireless headphones that had a solid mic, these have provided exactly that. 
Pros:
- Sound is really good, just make sure to mess around with the EQ settings in the Razer app (on Xbox).
- Build is pretty good, it's comfy and my ears don't feel cooked after a session. I'm not a fan of the green but it's not like I'm looking at them while I play, so not a big deal. The detachable mic is very handy.
- It has a dedicated headphones app on Xbox, no other Xbox headset provides that. It also has a feature that allows you to hear yourself and your surroundings better when you're gaming, great feature for voice chat. 
- I was a bit worried about the mic, but it turned out to be great.
Cons:
- Absolutely not worth the price, while it is comfy and a good build, it's still cheap and $200 isn't justified. Get it for $120 if you can.
- Sometimes the audio gets choppy for no reason, while I have been able to eliminate the issues myself, I've heard users report long term audio issues, so keep that in mind.

All in all, I'm happy with it. I wish I didn't have to buy an extra headset in the first place, since I love my XM4's, but that's the way it is nowadays.

I am unable to turn it on to use for bluetooth without turning on the xbox, which is fine and how the Arctis was. Conversely, if I turn off the xbox the headset will automatically turn off even if I am connected to my phone which is just mind-boggling.

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] My son had broke a lot of the wired headsets for use with the Xbox Series X.  A couple of them only last a couple of months before he somehow broke or messed up the wires.  This has been great, no issues with connectivity, sounds great and has great battery life.  He also prefers the sound in these versus the TV, so the room is quieter, just not him.

The headset works exactly as advertised 99% of the time. In fact they are better than they're advertised as most of the time. I use them as my headphones for walking around the house, I use them for watching movies and the sound quality up and down the frequencies is amazing.

Problem is the way the headset connects to the Xbox. 

It connects using the same accessories function as the xbox controllers and remote controls. While this is an advantage being able to just connect straight to the console, no USB dongles, no wires, and all native, it also creates an intermittent distortion that cannot be remedied. It turns all your audio into a scratchy jumble to the point you can't make out what people in your party chat are saying to you. It only happens once in a while, but it's a known issue that has been around as long as these headphones have been on the market. 

If you're looking for a competitive "PRO" gaming headset, this ain't it.

The sound quality is very good for the price range.
They compare well highs and lows with many $200 plus headphones. I like the ability to listen from two different sources and have separate volume adjusters. I sometimes experience poor  connection beeping issues when using my desktop
But I feel it's due to a bad Bluetooth transmitter on my PC.

Very nice headset at a sale price, but not as good as I had hoped.  Volume is good, with minimal distortion, however I found connection issues when using the app for controlling the equalizer and other customizations.  Headset could be more comfortable if the head band had thicker padding and covered a little more area on top of the head. Ear cups did a good job covering my ears but I found them to be a little loose.  I have an average size head and felt the cups could use a little more clamping force.  Overall sound was good and could be modified in the app directly from the Xbox.  Positional accuracy was very good when using Dolby Atmos.  Battery life is acceptable and as advertised.  I like the lighting on the ear cups, however it does take a toll on battery life.  I found it cut the battery life by approximately 25%.  Build quality is good and I have had no  problem connecting to my iPhone.  Firmware updates require access to a PC.  Updates are not possible on a MAC.

Ive had this headset for about give or take 2-3 weeks and it sounds beautiful with the EQ adjustment in the app and the firmware updates its recieved. my game ive been using as a main tester for this headset is dying light 2 and it sounds amazing! HOWEVER there is one flaw aboutthis headset that nobody has pointed out and thats the power it pulls from the RGB part of the headset to give it life. The RGB of the headset drains the battery faster and pulls power from the drivers which in turn distorts the audio of the headset. If anyone headset shut the RGB off and turn has issues with that shut the RGB off and itll fix the audio issue. Otherwise with the headset its great quality just more functionality on the manufacturer side, I WILL UPDATE ONCE THEY RELEASE FIRMWARE TO FIX THIS.

The only reason I gave four stars instead of five is due to recent patches done by Microsoft Edge that won’t allow XOBOX Series S/X users to download the program needed for use of the custom sound mapping EQ program. All in all these are great headphones and well worth the price. You will have four preset sound choices to choose from even without the custom mapping. The sounds of gunfire in BF are crisp and rotor sounds are more realistic. Heavy explosions are deep and definitely will add to the immersive experience for any gamer.

The headset is fine, but worth $200? Idk. The build quality is pretty solid despite it feeling like a cheap material. It’s relatively comfortable and light, a little tight at first but that gets better with continued use. My biggest issue is with connectivity. I’ve used it with the Series X and it connects well and the app allowing you to customize its settings is cool but, and maybe this is a problem with Xbox wireless technology in general, it tends to have poor connection with sounds pulsing. Like cutting in and out basically, idk really weird. Also you can’t turn the headset on without turning your Xbox on, which for me isn’t an issue but some might find it to be. Also the Bluetooth was one of the major reasons I bought this headset so I could use ot for both my Xbox and PC but apparently BT isn’t as far along as I thought. The headset sounds great through Bluetooth, a little delayed but that’s normal with BT but as soon as you try using the mic through BT the sound quality drops abysmally. Like unusually quality when it need the mic on Bluetooth. I ended up purchasing the Microsoft wireless adapter it was so unusable through Bluetooth.
In conclusion, decent headset in some areas, but really falls short in others.

The connectivity and sound are really good for a gaming headset. The fit is very tight and hurt the top of my head after an hour of playing. So I returned it and got the new Steelseries Arctis Nova 7x instead. Razer is great and if the black shark V2 worked with Xbox I would’ve got that instead because the black shark is really comfy. The Bluetooth connectivity of the Kaira Pro is a nice plus. Black shark doesn’t have Bluetooth.

Ive had the headset for a couple months now, the sound quality is reqlly good and I love the customization it had for the EQ. But if you are wanting to ever be able to use the mic without an insane echo or have every single noise in the background (like your heartbeat) go through the mic. Do NOT get this headset. The mic is absolutely atrocious! And it has nothing in the settings for mic sensitivity.

Replacing my broken Arctis 9x with these , and they are not far off in quality. Great fitment (I wear glasses too) sound quality is solid after updating and some custom EQ settings. Occasionally blown-out sound that was resolved by just powering off and on. Things to note - you can use an app on your xbox to customize sound/power saving options. You will need a computer to update them.

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] We had needed a new headset for a long time. We are a family of gamers and everyone knows a good headset is a must have. I love that this headset can be used for xbox and even on a windows 10 pc(as long as the proper adapter has been purchased). The headset connected instantly and sound quality was simply amazing and crystal clear. Others has been muffled sounds but this was not!

A lot of ultra portable mice meant for travel are so tiny and uncomfortable to use. MS got it right with the surface mobile mouse though. Opting for a similar design as their normal surface mouse but making it with a lower height profile keeps it far more usable, but lets it hide away in a bag really nicely.

Bluetooth connectivity makes it usable on most devices including android tablets/phones. [not that I see myself using it with my phone all that often, if at all.]

A nice grab if your using a surface go with matching pen and type covers.

The aluminum scroll wheel feels good and quality, Been using it daily since I bought it.

Connecting it to the surface was as easy as turning it on, setting it down next to the tablet and clicking the confirm button when the tablet asks if you would like to connect to the mouse. from there, it will automatically connect each time.

Powering the mouse on, or off is as simple as pressing the bluetooth button on the underside. Holding the same button while on will set the mouse back into pairing mode if you would like to connect to another device. 2 AAA batteries included. [the ones that came with mine were Duracell Brand, much like what they pack in with xbox controllers. so expect good lengevity.]
