When it worked i found it very useful but this unreliability is VERY frustrating! After fist experience i treated second one with kid gloves and replaced in box after every use.

This product is the first of its kind I have tried—and I’m so happy I don’t need to wear a heart monitor anymore!  I worried it might be difficult, but it was super easy to download the app, to set up the account, and to begin using the device immediately.  I sent my doctor my first EKG report without any problem.  The device is very lightweight and easily slips into a purse or pocket.  I am very pleased with my purchase of KardiaMobile.

I love that I have the ability to get so many different readings in one place but disappointed of the capability with the phone. 
Yes it does your sleep but I needed the capability of all stats being documented on the phone everytime I checked it. I didn't realize to get the BP/Pulse on the phone you had to manually go to the phone and do it. It is overall a good starter for someone who is healthy and only wants to check occasionally.

Every time I see my EP, I not only have something to tell him, but I have something to show him. I keep a record of my arrhythmia episodes so he can see how long and how often they are and with the AliveCor printed readouts, he can see exactly what my heart was doing. My readouts are part of my medical record. They have greatly helped in deciding my treatment path. AliveCor helps keep atrial fibrillation in my chest and out of my head.

The AliveCor app works pretty well. But a few comments. 1. Needs a battery voltage monitor from within the app. My unit stopped reading and only after checking the coin battery with a voltmeter was I able to know I needed a new battery. Worked fine after that. 2. Adjustable sensitivity? My fingers sometimes do not give a good connection. Bigger pads? (I have big hands.) 3. WiFi interference. The app should stop and say there is too much interference  to get a reading. Like it does if your phone is being recharged.  Saying that I still think the app is great. We are gone for 4 months in the winter and I asked my cardiologist about afib returning, after conversion.  He said it depends on the degree of afib. I've lived with irregular heartbeats for some time but also experienced doubled pulse rate. He said when in doubt just send him an AliveCor reading.

I am a friend of a 99-year-old and I am caring for him 24/7 at his home.  He saw an ad on TV a few months ago for the KardiaMobile device and we purchased it.  Over time I could see his heart rate becoming more erratic and even stopping for a minute after he climbed his stairs to his room.  This past month he started getting dizzy spells and collapsing at his dentist's office and at his dermatologist's surgical room.  At first I thought it was due to anxiety but four days ago he was dizzy and fatigued when he woke up in the morning.  His KardiaMobile show a very rapid prolonged heartbeat that was getting faster and faster so I called 911.  Turns out he has atrial fibrillation, ventricle dysfunction, and severe stenosis of the aortic valve.  I strongly believe the KardiaMobile device saved his life.  Now he can still look forward to his 100th birthday!

My husband bought me KardiaMobile but I was hesitant.  I had just been diagnosed with Afib and I find Kardia gives me some peace of mind.  I have a health watch, but that does not give me the rhythm - only the beats per minute.  This is easy to use and I can take it with me anywhere.  My only problem is that I have Raynaurd's Syndrome and my hands and fingers go numb, so I have to wait until the circulation returns to use the device.

Just what I needed to give me confidence knowing whether or not I was in afib or PACs etc.   I use when I don't feel quite right and want to determine whether my heart is in NSR.  Neither my PCP or cardiologist were familiar but impressed when I showed it to them.  Like to find out if there is a Medicare code for them if they read the ECG.   I have recommended this to relatives who have heart issues.   I ordered the cover to fit the Iphone.  This is too flimsy to protect my Iphone.  I end up holding the device on the bqack of the phone.  I was getting some reads with no diagnosis.  I suspect I was not holding the sensors tight enough.  I am getting the instant diagnosis now. I have recommended this to relatives and showed this to both my PCP and cardiologist.  Neither had knowledge of the device.  I think there is a Medicare code for the doctor to read.

Device constantly states I am in AF. Never records normal. States heartrate is anywhere from 98 to 110 when in actuality it is 68 -76 bpm. Scared me so I went to my primary physician. He got excited and ordered an EKG in office to compare and came back shaking his head. Stated I do not have AF and no indication of it at all. He  was not impressed with Kardia. I am open to the fact maybe I have a bad sensor or reader on mine........

My wife's cardiologist suggested she get one of these in case she had another episode. I opened the box, downloaded the iPhone app and followed the instructions. It worked great the first time! The real test is, "Can she use it?" I talked her through using it and it worked great the first time. We now have some piece of mind knowing that we can collect some important data for the medics and doctors should she have another episode.

I HIGHLY recommend this monitor.  It does all that the ads say it will do.  I have a pacemaker and monitor on my home that records what the pacemaker "sees".  This device has allowed me to take "30-second snapshots" so I can see what's going on when I don't feel up to par.  I have already been able to send some of those snapshots to my doc resulting in a change in meds without my having to go into the office.  Worth every penny!!!

I got this expecting a better reading, compared to other portable devices is average, does not detect some changes and it guesses most of the time, rarely gets bad reading, it uses sound so use it on non noisy environment and make sure the surface isn't vibrating.
Integration is very limited, I wanted to connect it to Google health, and other tracking solutions, this does not work that way, is aimed to the AliaveCor subscription.

The Kardia Mobile device was a wonderful purchase! It has been a life saver for our family! Our 11 year old son has endured 5 open heart surgeries thus far. Due to his complex CHD many times he will tell us something doesn't feel right or something hurts. All we have to do now is pull out our device and check his ekg. Thank goodness Daddy is an ICU RN and he can read it immediately. 
We can not say 1 negative thing about Kardia!

After two days of using this product, the signal integrity of connecting to my phone has dropped off dramatically and I am having issues with getting a device to work at all. The reliability is not there anymore and I do not use this anymore for testing because I don’t trust the accuracy of the test and monitoring your heart deserves the greatest reliability IMO. It appeared to work for the first two days seamlessly otherwise.

I found that if I have Bluetooth turned on in the I-Pad, the sensor had difficulty communicating with the I-Pad.  The work around I am using is:turn off Bluetooth wile using the Kardia app and be sure to point the little hole on the side of the sensor toward the microphone on the I-Pad.  The sensor uses a 19KHz audio carrier to communicate to the I-Pad and apparently the electronics is sensitive to the 2.4GHz Bluetooth signal.

My mother's cardiologist recommended we purchase one.  Several months after purchase used it to help identify she was experiencing atrial fibrillation.  Without this device's warning and a few other prods I probably wouldn't have been able to get her to go to the emergency.  This could literally be a life saver for somebody.
If you have a loved one with heart related issues you can probably benefit from having a KardiaMobile.

My AFIB occurrs once or twice weekly and lasts from between less than an hour to as many as thirty.  It is an annoying low heart rate form that does not impact my daily activities but tracking it is essential to my understanding it and trying to control it.  The AliveCor ECG readings and journal are invaluable in assisting me in this effort.  I record at onset and again when returned to normal sinus rhythm and make use of the data to help both me and my physician manage my condition.

I am the EMS Director for a volunteer ambulance service in a small Colorado mountain town.  We have outfitted our Advanced Life Support providers with AliveCor Mobile ECG units for their personal devices.  In the time that it takes to palpate a pulse and assess the patients orientation to person, place and time, we now have a Lead I ECG that we can email to Medical Control.  In addition to the obvious benefits of early baseline ECG in the vital signs, the patients are very impressed.

I bought the AliveCor mobile device so I could monitor my husband's heart if he started to exhibit cardiac appearing symptoms.  His heart malfunctions have also been subtle so I am often concerned when he describes symptoms to me that sound cardiac related.  Now I can at least run a single-lead ECG with my AliveCor device and forward it to his primary care physician at the VA.  It gives me a feeling I am doing something proactive rather than waiting around for worst case scenario.

This device is very easy to use.  I have sent a couple EKG pdfs to my desktop then attached them to MyChart for my doctor to read.  Once doing that, the forwarding process seems straight forward.

I am pleased with my purchase and glad such a device is available at a reasonable price.  It also covers weekends and holidays when the doctor's office is not open to do an EKG and when out of town.

Good job thinking thru the design for this device and for getting the FDA sign-off..

App is easy to use.  It takes a little practice to get your fingers on the sensor properly, but after you get the hang of it all goes well.  They keep trying to up sell you on their analysis service.  I have yet to figure out what good the cell phone holder is.  If you attach it to the back of your phone, you cannot see the app and put your fingers on the sensor at the same time.Guess they want you to take the sensor out of the holder.  Some hint on how to use it would be useful.

I've been using the Kardia EKG device and app since the original model. I record my EKG every morning to track my resting heart rate and have a 'before' trace available in case I go into a-fib. I think it's a great, in some ways revolutionary, medical device. Highly recommended.

There is one thing with the app that annoys me. It won't let you record an EKG with NFC on, so every time you go to record an EKG, you have to go into your settings and turn NFC off, then when done recording, go back into settings yet again and turn NFC off.  Like more and more users, I use Google Pay almost daily, which requires NFC. So, every day I have to go through several extra steps to turn NFC off and on. It would be great if the app turned NFC off and back on for you, automatically, as controlled by a Kardia settings button.

We usually perform standard ECG monitoring in our patients, but with patients experiencing unexpected arrhythmias I was able to quickly demonstrate the arrhythmia in the exam/treatment rooms.  Also demonstrates well to students in a classroom where they can see their own rhythms.  Originally ordered for iPhone 4, but able to still use with iPhone 6 (will transmit signal to the app if nearby), but would be nice if the cover had an elastic cover that would fit multiple devices.

I started out with the original version, and then upgraded to the newer one.  The wider/flatter contacts are much easier for most people to use (especially if they have relatively dry and wrinkled skin like my mom).  However, the new case for the iPhone 6 is a problem.  The edges are too hard and were the cause of a shattered crystal twice.  I would suggest getting the device and then attaching it to a third-party case or cutting out one of the leather cases to fit it inside.

I am actually in the health field as a respiratory therapist. I do plenty of EKG's. I was finding it hard to believe that you get anything just by putting a total of 4 fingers on 2 little pads. But I'm pretty impressed with this little gadget. I definitely recommend buying it if you have any heart problems such as A-fib.  Potentially this could be a lifesaver.. Of course don't take this as the official result of an EKG, but it can give you a hint that something is not right.

Easy to use and highly recommended by my cardiologist.  The advance reports from the cardiologist reviewing these rhythms seem to send blank responses without the sense of true interpretation.  Also, no one seems to catch my arrhythmia, but when I show the EKGs to my cardiologist, she can see my arrhythmia on the clips I am able to record.  I have atrial tachycardia and atrial fibrillation, neither of these have been caught by the app or the cardiologists reading the clips.

I was very conflicted on whether or not this was worth the purchase.  It’s a little bit difficult to get used to putting your fingers correctly on the pads, but you get the hang of it really quick.  There is no replacement for going to an actual doctor/cardiologist but I can tell you, this thing works if you’re looking to monitor for basic heart arrhythmias.  It’s a very impressive piece of equipment and will make a great addition to anyone who worries about their heart.

It is an important technology and provided at a very reasonable price. I am a cardiologist and have recommended it for years for my patients. It brings a great deal of insight for patients trying to sort out their various symptoms that may or may not be related to their arrhythmias. Having this insight makes living with arrhythmias, particularly AF much easier. I am a believer in converting acute AF from an unexpected medical emergency to an expected managable nuisance.

I am a retired anesthesiologist. I had been aware of occasional "skipped beats" for some time, which were never caught on ECG in the doctor's office. When I heard of AliveCOR, I hoped it would enable me to "be there when it happened" and record whatever was going on.

That is EXACTLY what it did for me. First, occasional atrial ectopy; later, variable P-wave morphology, occasional dropped beats and short runs of tachycardia. Eventually, 2 bouts of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.

Ironically, on the basis of these findings that *I* recorded, my cardiologist arranged for a 30-day telemetered recording _ which did NOT happen to catch any AFib. But on the basis of the AliveCOR tracings, I was started on apixaban anticoagulant.

Absent my AliveCOR recordings, we would still be "up in the air" about this diagnosis.

This is the most amazing device ever. I have been able to find out that my Father in law was in afib with rvr and was able to get him to a cardiologist before anything serious happened.  I bought another for my father and he was found to be in type 1 Second degree. I am monitoring him for any advancement into type 2. Alivecor has been the diagnostic tool that has made a difference.  I have shown this device to several cardiologists and they carry it on their phones now.

I naturally have atrial tachycardia and my med slow down my rate sometimes to sinus bradycardia. I always get the same "normal sinus rythm" reading everytime so I feel it will always read that unless I pay for yet another monthly subscription. Not sure how I feel about it since I know I have a not so normal sinus rhythm ( 2 surgeries have tried to correct) and do not want to have additional monthly charges for this device to tell me something than normal sinus rhythm.

I ordered this second Kardia because the first one had given up the ghost after 1 1/2 years or so I thought.  No.1 had stopped working. I put 2 different new batteries in it and still nothing. Wouldn't you know it?  As soon as No.2 arrived No.1 went back to functioning perfectly.  I can't explain it. I am well satisfied with the product and the help I received.  I have some medical training and in reading EKG's and I find this little device helpful with my arrhythmia.

I purchased this after having an episode of atrial fibrillation that put me in the hospital. While I worked with the doctors to try to figure out the cause, a friend who is a cardiac care nurse suggested this as a way to check my heartbeat when l was feeling anxious. The first test is read remotely by a cardiologist. I used it frequently in the first few months that l had it and occasionally since then. It works well and gave me much peace of mind in the early months.

I like the ease of use and felt it would be beneficial like a blood pressure monitor or thermometer but more advanced. When I showed it to my doctor, she suggested I return it. She felt it would create unnecessary panic. She had not seen or heard of them before so perhaps I wasn't providing her enough info on it. Will wait and show cardiologist for his thoughts. A friend's doctor thought it was great and the latest technology which prompted me to buy it originally.

It's a great product - however, it keeps not working when I want it to. My heart beat was acting up the other day, and I immediately went to the KardiaMobile to measure my EKG to send to my cardiologist, and it kept not reading my heartbeat. It said there was no signal, however, the device was right next to my phone, not near any phone charger or anything (apparently that affects the signal). It has happened a few times. There also is nothing to protect the device. There is a clip that sticks to your phone, but there is no hard case around it to protect it. So if it is bouncing around in my purse, or if I lay my phone down, it is going to wear out the device. The case that clips to your keys is also not a hard case, so if it is crushed by someone putting something on my keys when I'm not looking, it'll damage the device.

This works great until AliveCor cripple the device 30 days after purchase...    You can not save an EKG to your own device.. 

AliveCor extort users $XX per month in order to save an EKG.  

Thats crazy.. Its like Google and Apple charging $XX per month for users to save pictures on their phones that they take.. 

They also lock out even taking a screenshot of an EKG..

This is ridiculous business model and very poor execution of an incredibly valuable technology.

I'm on my second-generation AliveCor (I bought the second to use with my iPhone 6) and I have loved both of them. As an A-Fib sufferer, it gives me great peace of mind that I can easily get a heart reading at any time and send a copy to my cardiologist if necessary. When I have had A-Fib episodes, the AliveCor monitors have correctly given an "A-Fib detected" message. I have recommended AliveCor to friends and family. It is a fantastic device at a bargain price.

I bought this one for my middle aged daughter, in hope she will monitor her heart health. I bought one for myself years ago after I had my second heart attack. I talked to two of the cardiologists that have treated me and both told me the same thing. The algorithms in these devices are very good and give an accurate reading. Use mine a couple of times a week or when I sense an unusual heart beat. I tell all my friends and relatives to monitor their heart health with their doctors on a regular basis, because you never know what is going on inside your body until it's too late sometimes. After all I had my first heart attack when I was only 38 and yes it took me by surprise . This little device is worth every penny if for no other reason than peace of mind one gets with having an accurate idea of how their heart is behaving.

How often have you been wondering what goes on inside your body? Now it is at your finger tips. (Literally)  This device can give you an insight to your heart and what your body is doing tied to your heart. I love this device. I am an active 50 year old man and workout a lot. This is just a way for me to see if there are any changes and collect some information. You will have a graph in seconds so you will be able to see what going on with your heart. Thank you

Does a good job of on-demand recordings, provided you can be still for the reading.  For catching occasional arrhythmias it might not be best as it takes enough time to open and initiate the app that the arrhythmia (in my case) has often terminated.  One word of caution -- don't get the device wet!  I'm on my second one as my first one went through the washing machine (was not affixed to my phone).  But I guess I like it enough to have bought the replacement!

I have a consistently low heartrate and very often am below 50 bpm. With my original app this wasn't a problem but when I upgraded to the current app I can only get a reading when my HR goes above 50. Very Disappointing! I also find that the current model of AliveCor doesn't pick up the signal from my fingers as well as my first one did. If I try them one after the other the older one consistently sends a stronger signal to my iPad than the newer model does.

I had the Alivecor glued on the back of my iPhone 6+ in my right front pocket when I was pulling on a crow bar.  The bar let loose, crashing into my pocket.  The Alivecor plastics all cracked, but my iPhone, the Alivecor itself and, most importantly, my groin and vital organs were all saved!!!  Thank you Alivecor!!  True story.  But, in all seriousness, the device is wonderful.  It saved my mother's life (Afib) more than once...easy to use and very helpful.

I am a retired physician (gastroenterologist) with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation who was given AliveCor by my cardiologist son. I take some credit for demonstrating/selling your product to other physicians, and patients with cardiac concerns.. Fortunately, my rhythm disturbance is under good control, but it is nice to be able to check my ECG, if I sense my rhythm is not completely regular (like when my University's football team is playing in a Bowl game!)

On my second unit. First one failed and was replaced without question. Kudos to product support in that regard. Second one is not reliable. Without any change in procedure, unit will complain of interference one time and then read acceptably another. I have tried every suggestion in the manual to solve the problem. It has discouraged me from attempting to use it so , therefore it is useless and a waste. Too bad since I would like to have a reliable device.

I have used the device for only 2 weeks and have been satisfied. Initially I had a problem getting a report. I went on line to your support department that responded promptly and was very helpful in pinpointing the problem:My hearing aids were causing interference. My AliveCor mobile has worked fine ever since . Even though my doctor is the one who recommended the product, I am her first patient using it and she is impressed by the results. So far so good!

Works as advertised, but provides limited results unless the user purchases a 'plus' annual subscription.  It comes with an attachment with which the monitor can be carried with your cell phone.  If you have AFIB, or flutter, or other heart rhythm issues the monitor can provide your physician (or the ER) with information about an event.  This device was recommended by the electrophysiology cardiology nurse practitioner I saw for a one-time episode of AFIB.

I haven't used the new one yet that I ordered.  Still using the one I bought two to three years ago.  I had asked before how long it lasts and was told about two years.  I don't use it every day just when I think I'm having an AFIB episode which is about every three to four months on average.  It varies.  The only thing I don't like about it is that it is very sensitive to electrical interference (like my fridge), so I would have to take it somewhere else.

As i'm over 60 now and regularly see a cardiologist, i found that the information provided by this device is easy to use and to share the readings with my medical providers. By loading the client software on multiple phones, you can easily have additional family members get their EKG readings. There is an option for cloud storage, but I found the price not worth the price. I use the device a couple times a week and have been very pleased with the purchase.

My episodes with AFib have been few and are usually many months apart. So monitoring them with AliveCor and sending the info to my cardiologist helps with deciding if any treatment is necessary. It also puts my husband's mind at ease, knowing there is a way to get information to the doctor when it happens.  If you go to the emergency room or make a doctor's appointment you are already better and there are no symptoms for them to monitor or test. Thanks

To be able to know immediately my current cardiac condition provides great relief from needless concern, or provides a basis for taking action. The device and app have changed our lives and gives a wonderful sense of security by giving immediate and surprisingly detailed information.  Being able to send results for evaluation to AliveCor, or directly to my cardiologist creates immediate solutions for concerns.   It is an astonishing device and program.

I purchased a KardiaMobile device in 2018 and it worked well with my Motorola phone for three years.  Suddenly and for no good reason my phone was removed from the compatibility list.  I contacted AliveCor but there was no resolution. Now I have a worthless Kardia device unless I buy a more expensive mobile phone.  My Motorola phone is fully updated with Android version 11 but it isn't "good enough" for AliveCor.  So much for reliability of a product.

I love my Kardia! Since I received the monoclonal antibodies for covid I have developed heart issues, mostly POTs symptoms. My heart appears healthy on imaging but I fluctuate between slow and rapid heart rates, accompanied with significant chest pain. I can’t keep going to the ER so I bought Kardia and it’s been great! Thank you to the creators! It’s a game changer and essential for ppl with heart problems who want to take control f their own health.

I have been using an AliveCor ECG to monitor my heart rate and rhythm for more than one year.  It is easy to use and the information is beneficial for those who have a history of atrial flutter or atrial fibrillation.  Occasionally, the AliveCor will fail to save the first reading of the day, but it usually will save the next reading taken and it is not  big issue with the unit.  Great value for money and an excellent way to monitor your heart health.

AliveCor is a wonderful product.  It has helped me to document AFIB events so that I could get the proper evaluations and medications.  For me as a patient, it is much better than wearing a heart monitor.  I have my cell phone with me during my waking hours, so I can check my ECG any time I feel that my heart rhythm is not right.  I really like the features that include saving the ECG as a pdf file and then being able to email it to my cardiologist.

Have experienced intermittent/brief heart palpitations for years and suspected undiagnosed AFib. Recently experienced a much more serious and sustained episode with symptoms of tachycardia and irregular heartbeat. KardiaMobile indicated “Possible Atrial Fibrillation”. Went to hospital where AFib was confirmed and treated. Great tool to aid in documenting new cases and also for subsequent monitoring. This device is the real deal and at a great price!

My husband recently had a stint put in his heart on the 17th, so I thought what a great tool this would be for a piece of mind for us both,  but was a Lil Leary because his not technical incline & his a man but needless to say I was very surprised he lived it and using it faithfully,  it was extremely easy to set up and user friendly,  I don't even had heart issues and have been considering getting one for myself... One of the best investments ever

I really like the product and have one small suggestion. There's no easy way to determine right and left hand placement on the sending unit. I was showing it to my primary care doc during a recent physical and had only the electrode plate. I held it backwards and of course the waveform was a mess. It's not a big deal but something indicating R and L would be helpful.   Also, are there any plans to develop ways to get a read during exercise? Thanks

My profound thanks to Alivecor for this exceptional device. I used it to track my unfortunate progression of rapid Atrial Fibrillation.  Having these printouts saved me and my doctors time, money, and energy. My learning curve was tremendously enhanced by this data - realtime and immediate feeback. The Alivecor staff have also been exceptionally responsive. I was encouraged to have PVI ablation and am pleased to say, I am Afib free ! All the best

I've used the Alive Cor Mobile ECG both personally, and for patients in my medical practice. I love this device! It is great to be able to get a rhythm strip instantly, anytime, anywhere from my patient and they can send it to me instantly.  Because they nearly always have their cell phone on them, I think this device is superior to a holter or event monitor for very infrequent or episodic palpitations or rhythm disturbances.  Highly recommended!

It allows me to go beyond just taking a blood pressure reading and a heart rate.  I am able to take a Lead I or II or III or a pericardial EKG of my wife's heart following her 2nd open heart surgery.  I know her pattern like the back of my hand but if I notice discrepancies I have a board certified cardiologist just an email away to give a professional analysis, which I can then pass on to the doctor, if need be.  It's the best $ I've ever spent.

I'm a medical professional who has taught cardiology. I also have a history of an irregular heart rate. I find this little device handy for those sudden bouts of arrythmia that would, normally, come and go without a trace. It's like a gotcha-moment for the heart! In any case, I can only speak from a professional position, and, maybe, a novice may have difficulty with interpretation; however, it doesn't take away from the excellence of the device.

I always know what's going on with my heart, normal sinus rhythm,A-fib,Atrial flutter.
Of course I could always get the same information by wearing a Holter Monitor and getting an appointment with my Cardiologist for a reading, and  paying him several hundred dollars.
So much easier to buy this very inexpensive ecg which I always have with me.
I attached mine to the back of my S5, then used a razor to cut the case, simple,effective,and cheap.

Bought the device and thought that it offered at least some flexibility with use in terms of what I had to pay for verses what comes "free".  Wrong.  Despite the solid price of the hardware, I was not able to measure my ECG and have it come up with a report UNLESS subscribing to additional payments.  I would never dream of doing this as a patient, unless I was a gullible one.  Less value than I had hoped, and falls short of expectations.  Next!

I bought this device, Hoping it would be more Accurate. It's not. I have Arrhythmias and my Smart phone has an App that will detect them. Kardia Mobile, Once and a while get it right. But most of the time it will Show that I have Arrhythmias but Tell me that I have a Normal Sinus Rythm. A couple of times it said I had Tachycardia and Premature Ventricular Contractions. But again, that was Rarely. I Believe my Phone does a better job without it

I have an AliveCor  Mobile ECG unit for my iPhone 5S.  Several months ago, it quite working.  I replaced the battery with no change in condition.  Can I purchase a replacement electronic component without purchasing a new case?  My case is in perfect condition.  I simply need new guts.  I can't begin to tell you home many times I have demonstrated my AliveCor unit to physicians, friends, business associates and acquaintances.    Thank you, Jim

Dr. prescribed either KardiaMobile or an Apple Smart Watch to record my heart rate and track my sinus rhythm. The Smart Watch was more than 3x the cost of Kardia Mobile but does the same task. It pairs easily with iPhone and records data whenever I use it. The cheaper cost and making time to take the measurements outweigh the convenience of wearing the Smart Watch and just pressing the stem to get a reading. Covid times are unemployment times.

Great little tool.  Used it frequently prior to my second ablation.  Haven't used it in a while post-op.  I would absolutely recommend this to anyone suffering from arrhythmias.  I have a cardia background and have been a nurse 25 years.  This device allows you to email a long strip to your physician for a determination of whether to go to the ER of a physician's office.  I think it's amazing.  Similar to a telemetry strip but nothing like getting a 12-lead to view different leads.  I highly recommend it!!!

As a heart patient who has rhythm issues, I am particulary concerned about what my heart is doing when I start to feel those flutters. I have an ICD, and am at risk for Atrial Fibrillation, so any arrythmias may cause me a shock, or may even cause a stroke.  That is why the Alive Cor is so handy.  Now, I can just run a strip and send it to my doctor, and I can respond accordingly.  If it is nothing, I can go back to whatever I was doing, but if it is urgent, I can go straight to the E.R.  Thanks Alive Cor!

I purchased the kardia mobile 6L unit because my wife has suffered from a fib in the past, I was skeptical purchasing it because of the price, I set up the app on both of our phones on April 2nd and every morning we would test our ekgs, on the 26th we got up and I did my test and it said possible afib, I did it again, same thing, I had my wife try it. Normal. I wasn't feeling bad or in pain, just a little sweat. I tried it 10 more times before it convinced me to go to the Emergency room, they hooked me up to the professional unit and the doctor walked in and said yup I that I was full blown afib, and asked me what symptoms I was having, sweaty And the kardia mobile. I still have a hard time believing that I have a heart condition but I won't second guess my kardia mobile device.

I find the AliveCor Mobile ECG to be very useful and it helps me determining if I am in Afib or not.  In the future I would be a willing customer for more software and or hardware to give more detail and information on the BFx number. I notice with myself if I am climbing toward a 60 BFx then I am going into an Afib episode. As a Marketing Consultant, I can think of many product extensions for your company. For example ways to reduce stress and heart rate and waht one can measure one can change or control.

My wife is prone to an arrythmia condition called "bigemini" whereby every other beat is a "VPB".  This has been diagnosed and treated by a cardiologist, but we wanted to be able monitor at home.  When I tried my normal cardiac rhythm it showed a normal EKG, perfect.  However, when my wife tried it, it showed a EKG that was almost completely flat, with just a little blip where there was probably a VPB.  Since this would not show an accurate, readable EKG for her, it was worthless for us so we returned the unit.

We should mention that we were not attempting to view EKG for the the conditions that the unit is specified to diagnose, like A-Fib.  It's hard to say whether would recommend the unit since it may work very well for the conditions it specifies, but it didn't work for us.

I have found AliveCor to be of wonderful assistance to me for informing my doctor about the frequency and characteristics of the Paroxysmal Tachycardia I have.  I can also make notes in the AliveCor app at the time it happens.  My only wish is that AliveCor develop a way to directly send to my doctor the resulting EKG's I did.  I love that I can save them as pdf files, but most doctors, if not all, do not allow email attachments sent to them.  Right now one has to fax or mail the readings to the doctor.

Excellent device!  E A S Y to use, no training or instructions needed. None!  Anybody can do it. Really!  download the app to your phone, sit down comfortably and put the device and phone side-by-side, put 2 fingers from each hand on the silver pads, wait....BINGO!!  This device will tell you whether your heartbeat is in rhythm or whether you are in A-Fib.  IT WILL NOT DETECT HEART ATTACK.  You can "join" and have benefit of a doctor's opinion, etc., or still use it free without joining.     In addition, it is very small.... maybe 3 1/2" long and 1/4" thick, and so it will fit easily into your purse or pants pocket, and you can have it with you wherever you go.  FYI-- I recommend that you order the protective carrying case from the KardiaMobile company after you receive the device.

Definitely saved  my fathers life. He would not be here without this product . Thank you!!!!I recommend KardiaMobile to anyone who thinks they may have the slightest heart issue. Its a FANTASTIC way to not only monitor issues, but also provide information to a Dr, hospital , or family almost instantly. Again I would like to impress upon anyone reading this : MY DAD WOULD NOT BE HERE TODAY WITHOUT KARDIAMOBILE! Thank you for making a product with such awesome technology!  Thank you Thank you Thank you!

Your programmers took the easy way out in designing the ECG display.  Instead of imitating the familiar format of traditional ECG devices (where the pen is fixed and the paper scrolls) they made the "pen" move across the screen and "jump" back to the left when it reaches the right edge.  This is disconcerting and really unnecessary.  It should be fixed a.s.a.p.  The "delete" option is unnecessarily hard to find. It should be more clearly marked.  You should provide instructions for how to best remove the "sticky stuff" from the back of the device for users who don't want to attach it to their phone.  You should contact Starkey and work out the incompatibility between your software and theirs. While my Starkey hearing aids are active, your app does not "hear" your 3rd generation device.

AliveCor is so easy to use! You can see your heart rate and EKG as it records. You have the option to store or not store your EKGs. I think it's great that you get a monthly report from AliveCor that you can save/copy/print and take to your Dr. appt.  Great for those of us who feel our hearts "skip beats". Also, AliveCor provides a wonderful opportunity to "get to know your heart". I did not realize my heart rate is as low as it sometimes is.  Thank you, AliveCor, for being so easy and informative.

This device works! It worked right out of the box, no "syncing" required, no hassle. I was able to demonstrate to my doctor the frequency of my PACs. My cardio just dismissed the PACs as normal and nothing to be concerned about. With the ability to accurately monitor my PACs, I determined that the PACs were a side effect of amlodipine and got my primary care to change my Rx. With no amlodipine I have no PACs! My doctor thought the AliveECG was so cool he bought one for his son who is in med school.

I have intermittent and rare AF that is not symptomatic.  I carry the Alive Cor with me in my travels along with the various meds I take, and when I'm uncertain about my pulse, I use it.  It's very easy to use and certainly provides excellent rhythm information.  However, p wave detection is only intermittent (even when I'm in sinus rhythm), so it's of little help, even when I use it with a small tube of electrode paste that I also carry.  Non-the-less, It's a valuable accessory and worth the cost.

When you install the app, it requests permission to use the microphone in your tablet/phone.  I believe the link is audio.  My EKG monitor worked out of the box.  As signal strength weakened, I replaced the cr2016 battery.  Signal strength was strong but ALL recordings were "unreadable".  I found that with a new  battery and strong signal, the monitor HAD to be a minimum of eighteen inches away from the tablet/phone.  Then it worked fine again.  Understand that this is the less expensive model, that works with two finger contacts.  The other model includes a bottom contact for your left knee  in addition to the two finger contacts.  It gives more sophisticated readings.  Recordings are saved to your tablet/phone OR you can buy a  service that will upload readings to your doctor or cloud.

Sending my ECG directly to my doctor enables me to be less anxious when my heart rate varies. It makes me more confident and keeps me  from running to the doctor or urgent care center.  When I talk to my doctor he can easily give me advise over the telephone of how to tweek my meds. He can then see how the subsequent change is or is not working.  It was frustrating to me when the mobile device did not work when I was on vacation and then when the battery went. It was too complicated for me to change so I was sent a new case.  It is also helpful since I live in two different states and can share the results easily with both doctors.  I am still amazed that my readings can be sent wirelessly. This is a positive use of technology. I hope I can continue to use it after the 6 month study ends.

Pharmacist for 50 years suffered from atrial fib since  2016. I wished that i had this jewel in 2016 when I suffered the trouble  trying to convince my primary doctors  what atrial fibs  is and what treatment, THIS  jewel of the night 
will tell your tracing whether the atrial fibs are developed so you can stop and relax and or see your doctor or an emergency room at nite , this jewel  will give assurance
how y heart is functioning, I had a machine  20 years ago form Germany which was  worthless

I bought my Kardia mobile two years ago after my first incident of atrial flutter. It gave me great peace of mind while I maintained normal rhythm. Then when I experienced a second episode of flutter, my mobile confirmed it and I was able to provide detailed info to my cardiologist. After a successful ablation to correct my flutter, I again relied on my Kardi mobile for peace of mind. But now all I get are unreadable results - interference when I'm in a silent room with no electronics nearby, crazy looking tracing, and constant "did Walter record this?" I find it coincidental that I also CONSTANTLY get asked to upgrade. NO! I don't need that. I just want the device I bought to work properly. It may be time to get a smart watch with built in ecg because Kardia mobile is clearly not the answer.

I have had the AliveCor. app and sensor for about 1 yr.  I take an ECG once a day and also whenever I feel/suspect my heart has gone into atrial fibrillation.  I email all ECG's that AliveCor categorizes as AF to my cardiologist.  Between my 6 month scheduled checkups I had an increase in AF events and my cardiologist, without me coming in for a visit, prescribed Metoprolol and I have not had an AF event since/4months.  I am very happy with the teaming of the AliveCor app and my cardiologist.

Your heart (or at least my heart) doesn't function on a 9x5 M-F schedule.  It is after hours and sometimes long after midnight that I get the feeling that "something is not quite right".   AliveCor is there and documented for me several A Fib situations that I could then share with my cardiologist.  Proof that something went wacko for a while.  I love the device.  It is super easy to use.  And, after 30 seconds, there is an analysis of what is happening.  Again, this device is "A must have!"

This product works very well. I bought it for my husband and myself. I did attach it to my phone so that we would always have it with us. However, that makes it a bit more difficult to use because you cannot see when it actually starts, so you need to do a countdown. 

This does not let you know if you are having a heart attack, that is what they say, but it will let you know if there are any rhythm problems. This can be a handy tool to share data with your cardiologist or general doctor.

Diagnosed with Afib in July 2012 after CABG surgery. Very symptomatic Paroxysmal Artrial Fibrillation. Had one Cardioversion and 2 catheter ablations. Now in Normal Sinus Rythm. The AliveCor Mobile ECG has given me Peace Of Mind like nothing else. Once your have had AFib you are always waiting for it to come back. The AliveCor device helps me to know what those strange sensations in my chest are. Now where ever i am at i can tell whats going on. Thanks AliveCor for giving me my lif back.

My cardiologist and arrhythmia docs are currently trying to figure out my abnormal heart rate, but even a 7day Holter only showed a few signs of the "weirdness". My arrhythmia doc suggested I get one of these monitors to carry around with me, so he can have a comprehensive idea of my rhythms over a longer time. This device has caught a few instances of concern and it allowed me to send it to my doc and a registered cardiologist for review! Absolutely worth more than it's weight in gold!

The Alive-Cor is a vey handy device to check for afib/irregular heart beat.  It is not diagnostic on screen but gives enough info for me to know if it's afib, flutter or PVC/PAC.  I find it reassuring to know what is and what isn't. When the Alive-Cor hit the market mid 2013 or so, my EP was so impressed with the clarity of info and print-out that he purchased one as well.   It is also a good ice-breaker and educational tool----"hey, what's that on your phone?"  Thanks for good product.

I have been using the AliveCor for about 6 months. At first I was getting a lot of non diagnostic readings, where I was not getting a Normal or AF. I was told to set the interference check and after that I was getting better results. I seem to notice however that if my heart rate is below 50/min that I likely will not get an evaluation. Sometimes the medication I am on lowers my heart rate into the 40's. My cardiologist seemed to be impressed when I showed him the readings. He ask me to record my EKG results with a blood pressure reading on the chart he gave me. Also, I think I get a better reading with only lightly touching the sensors. I think that the doctors could use the results, but they are not set up to automatically receive the records and filter the information to the patient's record yet.

It needs a hard flat surface to get good reading. If you are trying to catch a cardiac event rapidly it is difficult. You have to sign on, hit record and hope reading works and does not say too short to read. My Cardiac MD asked me to purchase as I did not want to wear monitor for another month, but most of my events happen at night, so you have to get up out of bed to make sure good reading. Does not work unless very excellent Wi-Fi connection, which at 3am is difficult to do in bed.

My cardiologist recommended that I pick up this little device once he suspected that I might have Supraventricular Tachycardia (SVT). This personal EKG device is awesome - it sticks right to the back of my phone, so I will be able to catch an episode no matter where I am. SVT is tricky to diagnose, so it mostly has to be caught at home on your own. We are hoping to catch a reading on the Kardia so that I can officially be diagnosed. Don't forget to use your HSA funds if you have them!

This is the second AliveCor phone case I have bought. The first was for an iPhone 5, bought when a Rx was required and at a higher price than today. When I inherited an iPhone 6 I purchased the latest case. It is more streamline than the original case and is made of a softer material. The upper right hand corner is cracked a bit and sometimes catches in my pocket. I hope that does not become a problem. I have come to depend on the device to monitor my AFIB issues and give me a good sense of what is happening and for how long. My EP Doc has used my emailed reports to assess my status. He is a supporter of this kind of device as a self monitoring tool for some of his patients. It is well worth the peace of mind it provides me.

I really utilize this device a lot. I'm 36 and a competitive cyclist, so I never thought I would need something to monitor my heart this way. My doctor stated my fibrillation was dangerous, so we did an ablation, now my heart beat is so slow they worry I won't wake up (28bpm resting). This device helps me to more accurately see when the heart is off or simply slow. The majority of heart rate monitors out there today, unless you buy a medical grade 12 lead EKG machine, cannot come close to the accuracy and information this device can provide. Especially in mobile form, this 30 second EKG reader is a unique and potent tool for understanding your QRS signature and the manner your heart responds when you are out living your life.

Had the AliveCor only a few days and returned it. It was okay and actually worked great once we figured out how to get it to work. Directions left a lot to be desired. Reason we did not like it is if/when someone is having an episode of pains, if you don't have this unit right by your side and your phone right there it is of no use. It is imperative to get a reading right away. Plus the unit has to be in a particular position with the phone for it to work correctly. If they could get it to work using other than Infrared then it might be worth 5 stars to us.

During the past 8 months, I have had atrial flutter and atrial fibrillation.  It gives me a very uncomfortable feeling in my chest, like a little guy is inside and beating me with a rubber mallet.  When this happens, I can take my own ECG and get a better understanding of what is happening.  My doctor also has access to this information.  Several times when I was in AF, I was able to talk with my doctor by phone and adjust medication and avoid a trip to the Emergency Department.  As they say, Knowledge is Power, in my case, Knowledge leads to Peace of Mind.

This device was easy to set up and easy to use.  It captures the information seemlessly.  The patient then has a document to send to their doctor.  I have irregular heartbeat and unfortunately the device labels everything as Afib which was unnerving.  I sent the report to my Dr and had to provide them with the password as well to open it, so when setting up, you should not use your personal passwords to access the report as it will have to be shared.  I will continue to use it should I have episodes out of the norm.  It’s great you can capture info 24 hours

AliveCor is not only amazing but is also addictive!  I am in my lower 40's and have been suffering form A-fib as well as other heart issues.  Being able to take EKG's on the spot has been incredibly valuable to my recovery process in terns of tracking.  The most important aspect has been the window it provides for my physicians into my health.  They see a true snapshot into my heart rhythms on a daily basis.  This insight has lead to better care and faster decisions on next steps.       AliveCore is a must for anyone looking to track their heart rhythm.  We can no longer depend on the small snapshot we get from a monthly visit to a doctor.  AC gives the complete story of our heart disease and is a critical component to recovery.

and AliveCor documented it.  Based on what I could capture on my own led to my ablation. This not only gives peace of mind; is it Afib or benign arrhythmia, it also means you're not attached to a cardiac monitor or an ILR to document what you feel.  I wish I had this 6 years ago when a cardiologist dismissed my vital signs, symptoms for 'anxiety or menopause'.  Thank you!  Change the settings to 2 minutes so you clinician has a better read.  Skip the BFx - it is confusing.  Add the ability to save or not save instead of going back to delete.  A flat monthly rate for x number of readings by tech and/or cardiologist in addition to a per EKG price.  Would to show 'benign arrhythmia' and 'tachycardia' in addition to 'NSR' and 'AFib'.

The product is wonderful and has enabled me to track and log my infrequent afib events.  I am impressed by the use of ultrasound (high frequency audio signals that I can't hear, but the phone can). Although I have found that certain loud environments cause interference, I have always been able to easily find a quiet spot to take a reading.  My only complaint is that there is no iPhone 6 Plus case available.  As an engineer, I would settle for a CAD model of the holes used in the regular iPhone case, because I could just cut holes in a case I already have.

As a user physician and as someone who adivises patients, relatives and friends, I am pleased to recommend the AliveCor Monitor and its application, that are being improved as I type, to serve persons with chronic, recurrent or hidden Atrial Fibrillation and other Cardiac Disorders that can easily be detected and quantified with a device that is now less than $XX.  I hope that the public in general and specially people like me over 60 continued to be educated about how this disorders can be timely detected, monitored and treated with the help of AliveCor.

I was recommended this as an option for keeping an eye on my arythimia with having to pay for a holter EKG and the hassle of wearing it and likely missing what the Dr wants to see. With the Alive core, I was able to record multiple instances of the abnormal heartbeat I wanted the Dr to review. I was also able to upload it and he reported back, talk about a time saver and life saver.  Great news to report, the beats are abnormal, but not afib, come to find out it was due to Nasacort. I highly recommend this to anyone wanting to investigate their EKG.

My cardiologist wanted me to get the AliveCor app because I had symptoms that were very elusive and he needed to get some sense of what a diagnosis I had. AliveCor was able to finally catch A-fib in one of my ekgs.  The doc was able to then prescribe the correct and appropriate medication for my heart issues which helped me greatly. I am grateful that I was able to get the information necessary to make me feel better.  I take EKGs most daily and on days I am not feeling well I take several. It is convenient and I get answers quickly. My cardiologist gets them quickly also and is able to make any adjustments needed to get me back on track. Of course nothing is perfect but AliveCor provides me with a safety net that I greatly appreciate.

The AliveCor itself works well.  There are issues with its display on my iPhone4s but the techs tell me it is my operating system and not the program.  Funny, but it worked well until the last AliveCor upgrade.  As for the Weekly AliveCor Report, it has never printed correctly on paper.  The email reads correctly, but when it's printed part of the daily results are always missing on the first page.  I have reported this more than once but still have no results.  This is not an issue with the phone OS.  I really wished the report printed correctly.

I just changed to an iPhone 6+ (from my 6), so I haven't been using the app recently because the sensor isn't on my phone.  Porting the sensor to a new phone would be a nice feature (sees stuck to my old case).  However, when I did use the sensor, and then the app, what I always wondered was, "I wish I could see a month at a time, and whether trends were improving or not."    Think of it like the Apple Stock Ticker app.  You can see just today, but with a swipe you can see the stock trend over 1Q, 1M, 1W, 3M, 6M, etc.  The analytics make the app.

I like the AliveCor Mobile ECG and the follow up reminders and service approach of the company.  However the device itself is very inconsistent at being able to record a good ECG.  I often have to try 5 or more times to get an acceptable reading.  Most are "unreadable".  I've tried different finger tip positions. Moistening my finger tips, using a sonic transmission gel on them, using a slightly salty water solution and moistening with various lotions.  All have been inconsistent.  My doctor gave me several 3M Red Dot transmission patches that have been the best help, so far.  But, I still, often have to try several times to get a readable result.  The product is generally, pretty good and useful.  But, the process is a little frustrating.

I would highly recommend the AliveCor phone app and monitor. I have lone AFib and my episodes happen several times a year. While I know when I am in AFib without the AliveCor, I find it very valuable to track the episode. My cardiologist is also pleased that he can review and assess the episodes.   It is very reassuring to be able to check my heart rhythm if I suspect that AFib may be occurring or if I simply want to track my heart activity during or after exertion.  I believe that anybody that has AFib would benefit from having the AliveCor.

I have had A-Fib for about 8 years now.  I am presently in sinus, but have had three (3) cardio-versions over the years.  This device lets you know immediately if you are in A-Fib.  I told my cardiologist that I had purchased this device and he thought it was a great idea.  He said he had heard nothing but good things about the Kardia.  I am so happy I purchased this great device.  Just one important suggestion, if you have dry fingers and hands like me, I strongly recommend wiping them with a baby wipe prior to trying to take a reading!  When I first purchase the Kardia and tried to get a reading, I would get either no reading or it would switch between no reading and a weak reading.  I saw the suggestion and it completely solved the problem!

As I turn 60, the aches and pains cause concern once in awhile. This device is no substitute for see your doctor, but it does allow for a quick self-check after exercising or more strenuous outside work. It works with my Android phone and the app that I downloaded. It never fails to communicate with my phone and the app. I assumed that my physician would disregard the records-- but actually he looks at the records on my phone and old me to keep using it. (I am not saying he endorsed it, but he said he would look again at my next appointment)

I bought my Kardia EKG after learning of it from my cardiologist. Two months later, it documented a recurrence of my hereditary atrial fibrillation. As a physician, I knew the tracing showed a fib, but I still had it read by Kardia's board-certified cardiologist on call. The cardiologist had 24 hours to read it, but mine was interpreted in about 24 minutes. I obtained two other EKGs that evening. One documented a rapid ventricular response, which fortunately did not last long.  The third EKG documented a return to normal sinus rhythm after the medications took effect.  Based on this documentation, my cardiologist changed my medications and I have changed my lifestyle. I recommend this device to my own patients with episodic atrial fibrillation.

Kardia is easy to use, convenient and was priced afforably. It allows me to record and save my EKGs so that I can show my doctor if necessary.  It is small so handling it is not a problem.  It was recommended to me by my cardiologist as a way for me to check my vitals. You can add additional items to your Kardia if you choose and interact with a knowledgeable person if you need to. As someone who was most likely misdiagnosed years ago it has given me the peace of mind to get off of my medication and be able to administer an EKG at any time.

My cardiologist recommended I get this, but, to be frank, I haven't needed it much because the fluttering I was having isn't happening anymore. 

However, I periodically use it anyway, just to have records. 

The device always registers saying nothing is wrong, which is a good thing, right? 

Don't know what else to say. It does what it's supposed to do, and it was not too expensive for the task. Plus, it also provides an added level of stability/protection to my phone, so when I've dropped it, I haven't had to worry about breakage.

[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] Without buying the extra add-ons (with monthly charges), this device is much less useful than I thought it would be. It starts off each reading with wildly fluctuating markings each time I use it only to declare “normal sinus rhythm” even when I can FEEL my heart skipping beats. And it can’t detect a heart attack—which is probably 90% of the reason most people buy it in the first place. Read the fine print before you buy. What they tout in advertisements you only get at considerable additional cost so the $79.00 price quote is misleading.

Product is easy to set up and use.  Once set up it will record basic 30-second EKGs that you can save and store as you choose.  It will detect some types of arrhythmia for the purchase price, but to get access to more types you need to pay a subscription.  Could you imagine a doctor telling you that they've listened to your heart and will tell you part of their assessment, but to get their entire assessment you'll have to pay an additional monthly subscription?  Unbelievable!  Capitalism without compassion, I guess.  I think that's lame!

I am quite impressed with this device to check ectopic beats and/or A.Fib within seconds. The wave forms with the enhanced filter is very smooth and the morphology is very consistent between individual complexes. Some times I get electrical interference, but interestingly if I open up the battery compartment and reposition the battery, it seems to go away. I would certainly recommend this to any one who would like to check their cardiac rhythm or PAcs vs PVCs etc, but would not recommend this  to diagnose heart blocks, MAT,u waves etc.

I have been using my Kardia ECG since June 2016. At first I had a few issues with getting a valid reading. After a little trial and error, it worked great.I am using it with an IPhone 5s. I have been fighting Afib and Flutter for several years. I have had 12 cardiversion and 2 ablations, with a 3rd ablation in the works. I have shared my use of this device with several of my heart doctors and several of the staff in the Cath Lab. When needed I send results to my email, then print them off for doctor visits. Thanks for the great tool.

Very nice tool but it transmits sound waves and requires the user’s microphone to be turned on. It is noise sensitive. Running water in kitchen or hissing sounds from industrial HVAC systems make obtaining readings difficult. Ambient sounds affect pattern. Positioning Kardia device with respect to microphone may render reading inverted. Just flip it around 180 degrees to fix. But I love having this device and I use it all the time especially when my heart develops symptoms. It’s been very accurate with doctor visit EKG comparisons.
The ordering process was great, but the item purchased was not all it was advertised to be. There is a lot of interference with it working correctly. The EKG strip tracing can not be relied on!

This app is so incredibly helpful and easy because now instead of trying to explain in lay-terms what I am feeling or why something seems amiss, I can record it in 30 seconds and have it documented for my cardiologist. The old saying, a picture is worth a thousand words, has taken on a completely new and expanded meaning. God bless you all for your efforts and dedication. Monumental good is coming from your work and I suspect that over time, this little piece of scientific equipment, will lead to astounding results for all mankind. I am so very grateful for your efforts!

Love this product! I have the blood pressure machine that belongs to the same name as this product. And also stores it’s information with the same app. That is actually how I found this product. I decided to give it a try. I sometimes have a heartbeat that skips and wanted to keep an eye on it. This product is pretty easy to use. And has the option to have it sent over to your doctor. It can help categorize what your irregular heart beat is in terms of if it’s super serious where you need to get to the emergency room or if it’s undetermined. Both my husband and I use it.
This works very well. It gives both an EKG graph as well as beats per minute and a warning if BPM exceeds 100. It connects easily to a smart phone. I’m glad I made the purchase.

i am satisfied with the overall performance of the product.  it gives me an idea/picture of my heart rhythm most of the time.  sometimes it goes awry or is hard to interpret.  my pulse rate from the product at times will be WAY TOO HIGH mainly after doing cardio at the gym.  one time it read over 200 bpms, when it was around 100. at times it reads certain bpms during part of the 30 seconds and would vary differently (high and low) from the earlier readings without any change in pressure or movement. it can be sensitive to noise also.  also, since the upgrade earlier, it can be a pain to edit/delete the entries in the journal.  it's a pain to get the edit/delete option to appear.  you should go back to the older way.

Very easy to work with and doesn't require a bluetooth or wireless connnection to function. It uses the phone's microphone instead. Only real "downside" to this is it does need to be in close proximity to the phone for detection and NFC must be turned off. 

It does have a monthly for a free "diagnosis" of EKG results once every 90 days. But if you're just looking to monitor your own results and send them on to your doctor, it allows for a PDF to be saved to the phone and forwarded on. 

It even allows for guest usage so it doesn't add to your personal stored results.

Kardia mobile lasted 2 years and then had to be replaced.  Along the way it killed a couple batteries but gave no battery alert other than starting to function erratically.  It won't work unless I turn off my hearing aids.  In spite of these issues, I am pleased with the information it provides (most of the time).  Occasionally it can't record an ECG due to interference - I've never been able to identify the source of said interference.  My cardiologist was pleased with the reports - although the backup cardiologist at the VA was simply confused by the monthly report.
I guess it does what it is supposed to, but I don’t see how it is significantly enhanced over what I see on my Apple Watch. I’m not thoroughly impressed.
Works and looks exactly as described. Easy and fast to setup the app. Easy to check your rhythm. Absolutely worth the cost.
The backing to the adhesive on the phone clip will not come off. The removable strip will not separate from the adhesive.
There’s a learning curve involved but once you get it it’s easy and it’s goid to see if there’s a change in heart rhythm.

As an easy single-lead EKG machine, this device works reasonably well. If your only diagnosis is atrial fibrillation and you own an iPad or iPhone, then you really should have this. My only reservation is that the signal is just not clear and steady enough for several other diagnoses. There are many other electrical problems that can affect the heart, but this device is not much help with them. Still, it has its place. I use it for routine monitoring at least once a week, and I am very glad to have it. When used together with an inexpensive blood pressure cuff, it can give you peace of mind when you are doing well, and warnings to head to the ER when you are not. Just remember that it cannot possibly replace a full EKG.
Purchased, pick up was easy.  Product and app were easy to understand. Positioning of unit to my iPad works well

I bought this EKG monitor for my mom and the first one I received came empty with AAA batteries in it, it required me to go back to Bestbuy and swap it out. However, the second one I received worked great, it was small and easy to use. It has all the information for the doctor to decipher for you to make sure you are healthy. It's not something to rely on out, but it does give peace of mind for certain health conditions. I'm giving it a 4 stars mainly because sometimes it will spit out randomly out of range data, but the solution to that is to test multiple times.

Excellent price for a 1 lead EKG heart monitor. Easy to setup and use. Download the app, connect with bluetooth, and place both left and right hand middle nad index fingers on the lead and you can watch your heart rate cardiogram. There is a subscription portion to this which allows you to detech othr heart issues, but I think the basic would be good enough for most people. And if you're really worried about your heart, I would pay for the subscription. Allows you to PDF your EKG to send to your doctor which I think can be useful. You don't need an apple watch to do EKG for your heart, This one does it better and only $70 when I purchased it. 5 stars if it came with premium subecript free for at least a couple of months.
I am very pleased with kardia mobile, it records very well and and I have had no problems
Awesome working device you can carry with you wherever you go fits in your pocket.

I was excited when Alivecor was released after hearing about it for quite a while. I now have had it for over a year. I trust it meaning when I get a trace I feel that it is valid. The one continuing problem I have is that people have trouble holding it so that it works. I hold it and it initializes but then they hold it and nothing. back and forth as I coach them "Not so tight" or "Tighter" and clean or moisten the contacts. I do like the new feature which gives an opinion - Normal - if it is. Overall I am very satisfied with my Alivecor and would buy it again.
Very helpful when monitoring heart functioning.  Recommended by cardiologist.
Very small so very portable.  The app was easy to set up. Great device!
Easy to use device thx for the quick delivery Rob what else do you want

I am very pleased with the AliveCor reliability. There are a few software problems, mostly in notations about patients. It's not very intuitive, and sometimes I have to search for the right input areas. Filing is definately substandard, it would be grand to be able to search under last or first names, or an alias. I would greatly appreciate a more stable baseline. The ECG doesn't appear to become "quiet" for too long, and any muscle movement aggravates the baselilne, causing adventitial "events." However it is greatly improved from when it was first introduced.

I am an emergency medicine and critical care medicine physician. This device can save lives. I responded to a code blue on the hospital floor. The patient was not hooked up to a monitor. I turned on my AliveCor and saw that the patient was in VTach and shocked the patient as soon as defibrillation was available. Patient survived!
It is also a piece of mind. When a teenager fainted in a hot venue, I knew it was a simple feint from standing in the heat, but AliveCor was able to give the parent piece of mind that her daughters heart was fine!!
I love this product!
Very handy and portable unit to have to give you piece of mind.

I was a long time undiagnosed A-Fib sufferer, who was finally correctly diagnosed just over a year ago. A friend, who also happens to be an Electro Cardiologist, suggested your product just to monitor my condition. He thought I might be surprised with what I found with a closer daily/hourly monitoring... After 2 months AliveCor monitoring the results indicated I might want to consider options other than just treating my condition with pharmaceuticals. This product was an integral part of the decision making process to opt in for a successful Catheter Ablation.

I absolutely 100% love love love this product. It has allowed me to take control of my AFib through my ablations and cardioversions. Always has been spot-on with its  readings. Just need to make sure you are not touching anything electrical or battery operated when taking a reading as it's so sensitive it will pick those things up and get confused. Before I would listen with a stethoscope and try to see if I was in Rhythm or worrying about my heart now I can take a measurement and know where I'm at to keep myself healthy. 100 stars

have been using AliveCor for several years.  Began use it in teaching clinics for prompt feedback to students, and then became especially helpful to me due to substantial time spent in remove areas. I can now review EKG to monitor any symptoms for myself as well.  New changes in your program with warnings and regularity of rhythm seem useful, but I do keep getting AF warnings in tracings that cardiologists say is not AF.  Further development of that protocol appears to be needed (unless I need another cardiologis,t which I doubt?)

I recently had Afib and had a cardio version to get my heart beating properly.  The whole time before the procedure I wanted to see what it looked like but had no was of checking at home. After the cardio version I wanted to be able to check frequently if the problem returned.  Kardia Mobile was the answer.  I can now pull out the device and within 30 seconds check if my heart is in afib or not.  Super easy to use and I can upload of PDF of my session to my phone or email it to my computer.  I think this will be a real life savor!

The few times that this actually worked thrilled me. Unfortunately, when I needed it most, either for myself or out in the field when working with patients, the device failed to pair with my iPhone 6s. Both myself and others attempted to rectify the problem: we moved right next to the phone, we cleaned the device, we rebooted the phone, all without success. A few minutes later it would then connect, only to fail to do so moments thereafter. I had hoped that this device could prove clinically valuable. Thus far it is unreliable.

Works as designed if you are patient.  No pun intended.  Bought this as a gift for my wife and she was glad to receive it.  It just isn't as exciting as she thought it would be, but that is not the device's fault.  It's basic functionality could be helpful should you believe you are experiencing something unusual with your heart.  I suppose you could also test yourself routinely and make note of changes in your health daily or weekly.  This is a good item if you are interested in knowing some basic information about your heart.

I have been using the AliveCor device on the advice of my cardiologist for over two years. The device has captured my heart arrhythmias and let me share them with my doctor. This has given me peace of mind and a sense of control with my heart health.  Earlier this year I was on a mission trip to central america and we had a physician along with our group. The physician used my AliveCor to help diagnose a heart irregularity in one of the children in the orphanage! Wow, technology is great! Thank you dedicated staff of AliveCor!

I went years without a diagnosis for the rapid heartbeat I periodically felt in my neck.  I had a stress test and wore a heart monitor for weeks at a time but could never capture an "event."  With AliveCor I had the ability to take an ECG whenever I felt anything unusual.  After only two readings I had a conclusive diagnosis of paroxysmal a-fib from my doctor.  Now I use it to track my a-fib events and discuss treatment options with my doctor.  This is an example of a new technology that is easy to use and incredibly valuable.

As an inner city 911 Paramedic that loves cardiology, I purchased an early iPhone 4S AliveCor.  While eating breakfast with a good friend, he described feeling slightly dizzy and explained a few recent episodes.  His pulse was a tachy and irregular.  The AliveCor worked flawlessly in revealing uncontrolled A-fib. I sent the EKG to my computer, printed, gave him some Asprin and drove him straight to the ER.  I now keep my AliveCor available at all times, but use it unattached with an iPhone 6S. What an awesome product! Thanks.

I was referred to AliveCor by my Cardiologist to check on an irregular heart beat.  I was very unhappy with the product.  Mine worked maybe 40% of the time.  Did not provide the kind of reliability needed to monitor my heart.  Very frustrating to have an irregular beat happening and then trying to monitor it with AliveCor product and it not work.  Frustration got to the point where I stopped using your product all together.  Took it off my phone and no longer use it.  I consider it wasted money on a product that doesn't work.

Normal is not always normal in the case of multiple PVCs while in sinus rhythm these PVCs if over 20-30% can be of concern to a patient with prior cardiac issues.  AliveCor should warn clients if PVCs are over 20% with the same message it gives for AFib so it can be monitored the same way.  I've had two cardiac ablation for AFib and rely on AliveCor to monitor when I do not feel well and document for my cardiologist.  Saves multiple trips to the doctor.  Would greatly appreciate the above mentioned improvement to the system.

This is an awesome little piece of equipment that helps me keep tabs on my heart rate and anytime I feel like my heart is having a-fib. I am in healthcare and to me the rhythms seem very accurate. I wouldn't hesitate telling someone to get this if they are ever concerned about the heart rhythm.  One caveat is that if you want to know if you have any other abnormal rhythm, you will need to pay for a premium service. To me, I only needed to know if I am having a-fib or not and that is a free service that comes with the device.

I think the whole idea with this phone app is just wonderful. One thing though at the beginning I kept getting emails saying that I needed my recordings looked at by doctor. This cost each time. Then I found out later that I didn't need to pay that at all that it was already being processed each and every time. Why make it so unclear as to what you should do. And who was getting the money each time I had it read? I was doing 5 or 6 readings a day thinking that I had to pay for each and each and everyone. this wasn't right.

If your resting heart rate is below 50 bpm this unit cannot analyze your recordings--it will take your ECG but be unable to tell you whether you have any abnormal rhythms (or normal rhythms either).  You have to take your recordings into your doctor to be read.  So it is useless as a real time device.  If you are in a-fib and your heart rate is over 50 bpm, it will analyze the recording (but or course, you will already know you are in a-fib).

In short:  If you have a slow resting heart rate, this product is not for you.

I am a physician and recently converted to atrial flutter. I spoke with a tech at AliveCore. The EKG cannot discern flutter from normal sinus rhythm but will pick up fibrillation. I am satisfied with that honest answer and purchased the device for post atrial flutter to NSR( normal sinus rhythm) and documenting it. It's worth the $ and peace of mind and I am impressed that the techs are available 7 days a week. I would recommend googling a normal EKG and looking at atrial flutter/fibrillation and the difference between the two, for your own edification.It's not a perfect EKG but is always at your finger tips, if you'll excuse the play on words.It seems a lot of my friends have discovered this great technology. Thank you Live Core.The support number is 855-338-8800

had been having palpitations for some time, so infrequent thought to be PACs and likely they were.  Then they became more frequent with runs.  I did not want to bother with a formal holter monitor, so I showed it to my Cardiologist and he was impressed.
